commit_message:
Remove base_hosts_client for the reability

The service clients for the volume service are different from
the other services and it is a little difficult to read and
debug because that consists of multiple layers for v1 and v2.
That could be useful for the code optimization,  but actually
the merit seems small and unreadable.
This patch removes these layers from the volume clients.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I176ca1fefcb93b1cc071ab02a53f89571d129b3f

commit_message:
Add Check for notification_driver

Adding check for notification_driver before sending messages to
notification queue. If notification_driver is available then
messages will be send to the queue otherwise the message is
logged.

Change-Id: I75345cc909442ff03ad2276830b0781ee60f7266
Closes-Bug: #1452055

commit_message:
Re-architect ironic-multiple-compute-hosts

Much enthusiastic discussion has happened around how
dynamic-resource-classes can be a better base for this work. This spec
outlines how that should work, and what needs to be done to get there.

Change-Id: Ib13ead5da11d41933157099bfbf1bbf249d9fc24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/16/320016/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: In general, Ironic resources should be represented via dynamic resource classes.[0] That work lays the foundation for this spec. This spec intends to show what changes should be made to the ironic virt driver to take full advantage of dynamic resource classes, and make them less of a burden for operators. Flavors ------- While this work will not change any of the flavors code, it is important to note that a baremetal flavor using this work will not have CPUs, RAM, etc. defined in the flavor, but instead will simply require a single resource that is defined by a dynamic resource class. Resource tracking ----------------- First, compute hosts running the ironic virt driver must report zero resources to the resource tracker, as an instance cannot actually be deployed on the compute host. Rather, instances are deployed on the bare metal nodes and only managed by the compute hosts. So, `get_available_nodes` should be changed to only return one node, the compute host itself, just like the libvirt driver does. Then `get_available_resource` should return a bare resource dictionary, which exposes zero resources, as this does not need to be taken into account for scheduling. Baremetal flavors as described above will not require any resources from the compute host itself. The `nova hypervisor-*` commands will not work as expected for compute hosts running the ironic driver; admins should use ironic directly for capacity monitoring. Resource pool tracking ---------------------- Tracking the available resources for a given pool requires updating the `total` and `reserved` fields through nova's API. Given that nodes may be added to Ironic at any time, and that nodes can be automatically taken out of the available pool at any time (e.g. when a BMC fails), manually updating these pools will be too burdensome for an operator to do by hand. Instead, ironic will be in charge of managing these pools. The ironic-conductor service will count and update the related pool when a node in that pool goes in or out of service. A spec will be written for ironic to define this work in more detail. The operator will still be responsible for: * Creating the host aggregates * Associating the host aggregates with compute hosts * Creating the resource pools * Creating the resource classes * Associating the resource pools with the resource classes * Associating the flavors with the resource classes These should all be one-time tasks during the initial deployment (or the addition of a new class of hardware). Scheduling ---------- Direction of a request to a compute node is simple - the resource class is tied to a host aggregate, which is tied to one or more compute hosts. As the request will only require an item from the pool of that resource class, the scheduler will arbitrarily choose a compute host that can deploy an instance for that resource class. The actual choice of a node from ironic is also simple. The ironic node object will contain a new string field `resource_class`, which will be matched against the name of the resource class being requested. The driver's spawn() method will query ironic for matching nodes:: GET /v1/nodes?resource_type=IRON_BASE This will return a list of matching nodes. If the available count for the resource pool is tracked correctly (and race conditions aside), we can assume there will always be at least one node in this list. But, because there is time between the scheduler forwarding this request and doing the deployment, we'll need to handle the case where this returns no free nodes by bubbling an exception back up to the scheduler. A node will be chosen randomly from this list and deployed to, as the spawn method already does today. TODO(jroll) this is where people ask about capabilities and affinity; how do we handle this without forcing a difference resource class for each of them? A version of Ironic that supports resource pool tracking must be deployed before a version of Nova with this change is deployed. Ironic must also be seeded with values for the `resource_class` field for each node. If this is not the case, the previous behavior should be used. We'll need to properly deprecate the old behavior behind a config option, as deployers will need to configure different scheduler filters and host managers than the current recommendation for this to work correctly. We should investigate if this can be done gracefully without a new config option, however I'm not sure it's possible.None, though Ironic driver developers should certainly be aware of the situation.* complete the dependent work in ironic. * change the ironic driver to no longer report compute host resources. * change the ironic driver to select a node during spawn(). * deprecate the old behavior, once the new is determined stable.This depends on a new field and new behavior in ironic.This should be tested by being the default configuration, once complete. We should also test the legacy configuration until it is removed.[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/312696/ - Re-architected, based on dynamic resource pools.
deleted_lines: In general, a nova-compute running the Ironic virt driver should only register as a single row in the compute_nodes table, rather than many rows. Nova's scheduler should schedule only to a nova-compute host; the host will choose an Ironic node itself, from the nodes that match the request (explained further below). Once an instance is placed on a given nova-compute service host, that host will always manage other requests for that instance (delete, etc). So the instance count scheduler filter can just be used here to equally distribute instances between compute hosts. This reduces the failure domain to failing actions for existing instances on a compute host, if a compute host happens to fail. The Ironic virt driver should be modified to call an Ironic endpoint with the request spec for the instance. This endpoint will reserve a node, and return that node. The virt driver will then deploy the instance to this node. When the instance is destroyed, the reservation should also be destroyed. This endpoint will take parameters related to the request spec, and is being worked on the Ironic side here.[0] This has not yet been solidified, but it will have, at a minimum, all fields in the flavor object. This might look something like:: { "memory_mb": 1024, "vcpus": 8, "vcpu_weight": null, "root_gb": 20, "ephemeral_gb": 10, "swap": 2, "rxtx_factor": 1.0, "extra_specs": { "capabilities": "supports_uefi,has_gpu", }, "image": { "id": "some-uuid", "properties": {...}, }, } We will report (total ironic capacity) into the resource tracker for each compute host. This will end up over-reporting total available capacity to Nova, however is the least wrong option here. Other (worse) options are: * Report (total ironic capacity)/(number of compute hosts) from each compute host. This is more "right", but has the possibility of a compute host reporting (usage) > (max capacity), and therefore becoming unable to perform new build actions. * Report some arbitrary incorrect number for total capacity, and try to make the scheduler ignore it. This reports numbers more incorrectly, and also takes more code and has more room for error.Resource providers[1] may be another viable alternative, but we shouldn't have a hard dependency on that. A version of Ironic that supports the reservation endpoint must be deployed before a version of Nova with this change is deployed. If this is not the case, the previous behavior should be used. We'll need to properly deprecate the old behavior behind a config option, as deployers will need to configure different scheduler filters and host managers than the current recommendation for this to work correctly. We should investigate if this can be done gracefully without a new config option, however I'm not sure it's possible.None, though Ironic driver developers should be aware of the situation.* Change the Ironic driver to be a 1:1 host:node mapping. * Change the Ironic driver to get reservations from Ironic.This depends on a new endpoint in Ironic.[0]This should be tested by being the default configuration.[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204641/ [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/225546/

commit_message:
Add command to force a deploy failure

This can be used if a node gets stuck in a deploying state, as the
only option currently is to manually run a query in the database.
Operators should be able to run a script instead.

Run the command:
ironic-noderecover -h
ironic-noderecover --node_uuids=UUID1,UUID2  --config-file=/etc/ironic/ironic.conf

Partial-Bug: #1580931
Change-Id: I1256a81e26f16c8b450e65ee1b4524f47ae495cc

added_lines: # coding=utf-8 # # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from ironic.common import states from ironic import context from ironic import objects def force_deploy_failed(node_uuids): ctxt = context.get_admin_context() for node_uuid in node_uuids: node = objects.Node.get(context, node_uuid) node.provision_state = states.DEPLOYFAIL node.target_provision_state = states.NOSTATE node.save() if __name__ == 'main': force_deploy_failed(sys.argv[1:])

commit_message:
Node search API spec

Change-Id: I54e305a9d39f4a13239348b47e84b1b150abb261
Related-Bug: #1570604
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/92/306092/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============== Node Search API =============== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1570604 API clients should be able to search and filter nodes by arbitrary properties, such as those in node.properties, node.driver_info, etc. This allows scheduling systems to find nodes with the desired resources easier and with better performance, as well as allow operators and other tools to be able to find particular (groups of) nodes better. Problem description =================== Currently clients must implement their own scheduling mechanisms. Nova has a scheduler subsystem, but Ironic does not fit well within it. Other clients may integrate external schedulers, but if any do this today, it will necessarily be inefficient because they, like Nova, must fetch all resources from Ironic to perform filtering on the client side. If Ironic had a query interface and/or placement engine, Nova could stop dealing with individual nodes and deal with Ironic as a whole, while deployments without Nova could leverage Ironic for placement, rather than building their own engine on top. Proposed change =============== This builds part of that engine, allowing an API client to find nodes with a particular set of properties. Another feature, "node claims API", will allow a client to reserve one or more nodes, to be deployed to at a later time. To accomplish this, additional query parameters will be added to the ``GET /nodes`` API call, which are described in detail below in the API impact section. All nodes matching the query will be returned (with pagination, if applicable). Alternatives ------------ Implement an entire new scheduling service, akin to the one Nova already has. This would provide more customizability / pluggability than the proposal here, however it is significantly more complex than the proposal here as well. Data model impact ----------------- None. State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- lol. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- The additional query parameters should also be added to both CLI interfaces, as detailed below. "ironic" CLI ~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO "openstack baremetal" CLI ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ TODO RPC API impact -------------- None, all filtering is done in the API layer. Driver API impact ----------------- None. Nova driver impact ------------------ No direct impact from this feature, however this is work required to make this Nova work possible[0]. Security impact --------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- The horizon panel could add these filters, however it is not in the scope of this work to do so. Scalability impact ------------------ See performance impact section. Performance Impact ------------------ Some of the query parameters being added are currently JSON blobs in the database, and SQLAlchemy does not support JSON fields in MySQL. This will cause this API call to be very slow, as we cannot query indexes for these fields. The data model is being restructured as another set of work[1], in order to make this API performant. However, this work can be done in parallel, with this API being flagged as highly experimental (and slow!) until the data model work is done, in order to move forward on the Nova side of this work. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jroll Other contributors: lucasagomes, devananda Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ None, though this work[1] is required to make this performant. Testing ======= Tempest tests should be added for the new filters. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== API version will be incremented. Documentation Impact ==================== We'll need to add these query parameters to our API docs. References ========== [0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/approved/ironic-multiple-compute-hosts.html [1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1525376 Previous discussion on a combined search/claims API spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204641/

commit_message:
Remove ramdisk on unstack

Running devstack will not rebuild or replace the ramdisk if it already
exists. Remove it during unstack such that it is rebuilt or
re-downloaded during development, to avoid surprises.

Change-Id: Ifd29b3b8b583d9572358a85e6fa2a9f02ab092dc

commit_message:
Make port.save remotable

This makes the port.save() call remotable, and updates the API service
to use that method directly, rather than routing through an explicit RPC
method in the conductor.

Also deprecate the update_port conductor RPC call, as it's no longer
used. This should be removed in the next major RPC version.

In the spirit of live upgrades, we should be doing all writes (and
possibly reads?) in the conductor layer.

Change-Id: Ied2aa055d80d2a516f59001e560c97c743dcb0aa

commit_message:
Make port.destroy remotable

This makes the port.destroy() call remotable, and updates the API
service to use that method directly, rather than routing through an
explicit RPC method in the conductor.

Also deprecate the destroy_port conductor RPC call, as it's no longer
used. This should be removed in the next major RPC version.

In the spirit of live upgrades, we should be doing all writes (and
possibly reads?) in the conductor layer.

Change-Id: I91e509f6140a178df0a2283e7cd5d877712358ad

commit_message:
Make port creation happen in the conductor

This makes the port.create() call remotable, which will cause the API
service to send the call over RPC to the conductor.

In the spirit of live upgrades, we should be doing all writes (and
possibly reads?) in the conductor layer.

Change-Id: I6607649460b235ed2fc9fcd1474c636271cb2a71

commit_message:
Clean up port API code

This cleans up a few hacks we have in the port API code to work around
the fact that we expose node_uuid to API clients, but only track node_id
in the Port object.

It also aims to reduce SQL queries in GET calls for ports, by joining
the node in the query rather than issuing a second query for it.

Change-Id: If9738e3671c1679332c3c1cecb87fe998f3339f2

subject: Attach related node to Port object
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-29 17:23:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/cda28aae72608e82039548956a7f2a67f4658dfa', 'message': "Attach related node to Port object

This adds a 'node' attribute to the port object, allowing the node
object to be used directly from the port object, without explicitly
doing another query for it. A new ObjectField from oslo.versionedobjects
is added to support this.

The get(), get_by_id(), get_by_uuid(), get_by_address(), list(), and
list_by_node_id() methods on the Port class now all accept an optional
`expected_attrs` argument. This is a list of optional attributes from
objects.port.PORT_OPTIONAL_ATTRS to be eagerly loaded on the Port
object. The eager loading is done with a join in the database.
If the parameter is not passed, the node will be lazily loaded from the
DB on first use of the node attribute.

To support lazy loading, we define the obj_load_attr method on the Port
class, which is called from the o.vo base class when an attribute is
accessed that is not yet loaded on the object.

The _from_db_object now optionally loads the node object when requested.

The version for the Port object is bumped to 1.5 to signal this change
to RPC clients, and the hash in tests is updated accordingly.

The port objects tests are refactored, with coverage added for the
changes to the port object.

A hack (cribbed from Nova) is added to the object version hash test, to
look at a GENERATE_HASHES environment variable. If this variable is set,
the test will dump the version hashes into object_hashes.txt, allowing
developers to easily generate the new hashes when objects are changed.

commit_message:
Attach related node to Port object

This adds a 'node' attribute to the port object, allowing the node
object to be used directly from the port object, without explicitly
doing another query for it. A new ObjectField from oslo.versionedobjects
is added to support this.

The get(), get_by_id(), get_by_uuid(), get_by_address(), list(), and
list_by_node_id() methods on the Port class now all accept an optional
`expected_attrs` argument. This is a list of optional attributes from
objects.port.PORT_OPTIONAL_ATTRS to be eagerly loaded on the Port
object. The eager loading is done with a join in the database.
If the parameter is not passed, the node will be lazily loaded from the
DB on first use of the node attribute.

To support lazy loading, we define the obj_load_attr method on the Port
class, which is called from the o.vo base class when an attribute is
accessed that is not yet loaded on the object.

The _from_db_object now optionally loads the node object when requested.

The version for the Port object is bumped to 1.5 to signal this change
to RPC clients, and the hash in tests is updated accordingly.

A method obj_from_db_obj() is added to the Node object to allow
translating a node from the database into a Node object. The Node object
version is bumped to 1.15 to signal this.

The port objects tests are refactored, with coverage added for the
changes to the port object.

A hack (cribbed from Nova) is added to the object version hash test, to
look at a GENERATE_HASHES environment variable. If this variable is set,
the test will dump the version hashes into object_hashes.txt, allowing
developers to easily generate the new hashes when objects are changed.

Change-Id: Ibf933bcee54be876fd063131cd426ede6f1459a4

commit_message:
Allow port to join nodes in the DB layer

This refactors some of the DB layer to allow the nodes table to be
joined to the port model. It:

* refactors the DB API to accept a list of columns to join to the SELECT
  queries for ports.

* adds the 'node' field to the port model as a FK relationship to the
  node table.

* tests all the things

If extra_attrs=['node'] is passed in to a method that selects ports
from the DB, the related node row will be eagerly joined in the query.

Change-Id: I92e6c8ac6b43b0c8744af3ed02d6105f3d9f8830

added_lines: import mock @mock.patch('ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.joinedload') def test_get_port_by_id_join_node(self, mock_joinedload): res = self.dbapi.get_port_by_id(self.port.id, columns_to_join=['node']) self.assertEqual(self.port.address, res.address) mock_joinedload.assert_called_once_with('node') def test_get_port_by_id_join_nodeforreal(self): res = self.dbapi.get_port_by_id(self.port.id, columns_to_join=['node']) self.assertEqual(self.port.address, res.address) self.assertEqual(self.node.uuid, res.node.uuid) @mock.patch('ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.joinedload') def test_get_port_by_uuid_join_node(self, mock_joinedload): res = self.dbapi.get_port_by_uuid(self.port.uuid, columns_to_join=['node']) self.assertEqual(self.port.id, res.id) mock_joinedload.assert_called_once_with('node') @mock.patch('ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.joinedload') def test_get_port_by_address_join_node(self, mock_joinedload): res = self.dbapi.get_port_by_address(self.port.address, columns_to_join=['node']) self.assertEqual(self.port.id, res.id) mock_joinedload.assert_called_once_with('node') @mock.patch('ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.joinedload') def test_get_port_list_join_node(self, mock_joinedload): uuids = [] for i in range(1, 6): port = db_utils.create_test_port(uuid=uuidutils.generate_uuid(), address='52:54:00:cf:2d:4%s' % i) uuids.append(six.text_type(port.uuid)) # Also add the uuid for the port created in setUp() uuids.append(six.text_type(self.port.uuid)) res = self.dbapi.get_port_list(columns_to_join=['node']) res_uuids = [r.uuid for r in res] six.assertCountEqual(self, uuids, res_uuids) mock_joinedload.assert_called_once_with('node') @mock.patch('ironic.db.sqlalchemy.api.joinedload') def test_get_ports_by_node_id_join_node(self, mock_joinedload): res = self.dbapi.get_ports_by_node_id(self.node.id, columns_to_join=['node']) self.assertEqual(self.port.address, res[0].address) mock_joinedload.assert_called_once_with('node')

commit_message:
Make object methods remotable again

The remotable decorators were commented out when we landed the
indirection API code, because it was flaky and devstack. The change this
depends on should handle the flakiness by ensuring the conductor is
started before the API. Re-enable the remotable methods.

Change-Id: I2eba48b119ab72783d0d5290a8f22132df9d2efd
Depends-On: I8a0d92f5b158418f391bc9a0c37f116b529bc967

commit_message:
Begin adding dev docs for writing methods

This adds some basic documentation on writing methods inside Ironic. It
covers exception handling and docstrings.

Change-Id: I08924d25f7041b577e66a61cb75b16ce681e3907
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/11/232011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _methods ================= Rules for methods ================= What this document is ===================== This document describes rules for methods written in the Ironic project. Docstrings ========== Any contributions must include proper docstrings. All public methods (i.e. methods that do not begin with "_") should have a docstring. The docstring should contain: - A one-line summary of the method. - A longer description of what the method does. - A :param: block that describes each parameter that may be passed to the method. - A :returns: block that describes the return value of the method. - A :raises: block that describes each exception that may be raised by the method. Exception handling ================== A method within Ironic should only raise two types of exceptions: - Exceptions in the Python standard library - Subclasses of IronicException Methods that call to third party libraries should catch any exception that may be raised by the library, and wrap it in some subclass of IronicException to be re-raised. This makes it easy to document in the docstring which exceptions may be raised, and keep the docstring accurate.

Add docs and samples for running with uwsgi

This adds sample configuration and documentation for running
the ironic-api service behind Apache with uwsgi.

Change-Id: I6cdb48e940d3aa36cdbad3dd80eeaebe3d6d27a9

commit_message:
Add node claims/filter APIs

Ironic currently leaves all scheduling activities as an exercise to the
client. Let's help the clients by adding search and claim mechanisms into
Ironic.

Change-Id: I930912f98107d86f3beefe6343e46f419a229e46
Implements: blueprint node-reservations
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/41/204641/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================= Node Reservations ================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/node-reservations Ironic currently leaves all scheduling activities as an exercise to the client. Let's help the clients by building a scheduling system into Ironic. Introduction paragraph -- start here. Why are we doing anything? This should be a single paragraph of prose that operators can understand. Some notes about using this template: * Your spec should be in ReSTructured text, like this template. * Please wrap text at 79 columns. * The filename in the git repository must match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/awesome-thing must be named awesome-thing.rst * Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None * For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html * To test out your formatting, build the docs using tox, or see: http://rst.ninjs.org * If you would like to provide a diagram with your spec, ascii diagrams are required. http://asciiflow.com/ is a very nice tool to assist with making ascii diagrams. The reason for this is that the tool used to review specs is based purely on plain text. Plain text will allow review to proceed without having to look at additional files which can not be viewed in gerrit. It will also allow inline feedback on the diagram itself. * If your specification proposes any changes to the Ironic REST API such as changing parameters which can be returned or accepted, or even the semantics of what happens when a client calls into the API, then you should add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with the following query: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/ironic-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z * If you are unsure whether this proposal is aligned with the project's mission and scope, you are encouraged to submit a minimal spec to get feedback early, before investing the effort in a complete specification. Do this by filling in the `Problem description` and `Proposed change` sections and delete the rest of the template. This will fail unit tests, but will still get attention from the review team. * If you do not wish to submit a complete spec (for example, you do not plan to complete the spec during this cycle but would like to document the idea) you can submit a short spec. It must contain at least the `Problem description` and `Proposed change` sections, and may optionally contain any other valid sections. Propose this to the `specs/backlog` directory. This must follow all other rules of a regular spec (eg, it still requires a blueprint, good RST formatting, etc). Problem description =================== A detailed description of the problem: * For a new feature this might be use cases. Ensure you are clear about the actors in each use case: End User, Admin User, Deployer, or another Service * For a major reworking of something existing it would describe the problems in that feature that are being addressed. Proposed change =============== Here is where you cover the change you propose to make in detail. How do you propose to solve this problem? If this is one part of a larger effort make it clear where this piece ends. In other words, what is the scope of this effort? If you are unsure whether this proposal is aligned with the project's mission and scope, stop here. Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Has someone else done this thing in another project? In another language? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change? * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated? For example, if you need to take into account existing instances, or modify other existing data, describe how that will work. State Machine Impact -------------------- Interaction between the proposed change and the Ironic state machine should be documented here. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * Are you adding or removing any states or verbs? * Are you changing any state transitions? * What states are impacted by this change? This includes situations where an additional action is being performed on nodes in a given state. Any change to the state machine is also a REST API change, and should also be documented accordingly in the next section. REST API impact --------------- Each API method which is either added or changed should have the following * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does, suitable for use in user documentation. * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE/PATCH) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included. Describe semantic errors which can cause it, such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when a resource is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema definition do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * Parameters which can be passed via the url, including data types * JSON schema definition for the body data if allowed * JSON schema definition for the response data if any * Does the API microversion need to increment? * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. * Is a corresponding change in the client library and CLI necessary? * Is this change discoverable by clients? Not all clients will upgrade at the same time, so this change must work with older clients without breaking them. Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted. Use of free-form JSON dicts should only be permitted where necessary to allow divergence in the drivers. In such case, the drivers must expose the expected content of the JSON dict and an ability to validate it. Reuse of existing predefined parameter types is highly encouraged. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- Typically, but not always, if there are any REST API changes, there are corresponding changes to python-ironicclient. If so, what does the user interface look like. If not, describe why there are REST API changes but no changes to the client. RPC API impact -------------- Changes which affect the RPC API should be listed here. For example: * What are the changes, if any, to existing API calls? * What new API calls are being added? Will these be using cast() or call()? * ironic-api and ironic-conductor services must be upgradable independently. What is the upgrade process for rolling this change out to an existing deployment? Driver API impact ----------------- Changes which affect the driver API have a direct effect on all drivers, and often have a wider impact on the system. There are several things to consider in this section. * Is it a change to a "core" or "common" API? * Can all drivers support it initially, or is it specific to a particular vendor's hardware? * How will it be tested in the gate and in third-party CI systems? * If adding a new interface, explain the intended scope of the proposed interface, what functionality it enables, why it is needed, and whether it is supported by current drivers. * If adding or changing a method on an existing interface, the impact on existing drivers should be explored. * Will the new interface or method need to be invoked when the hash ring rebalances, for example to rebuild local state on a new conductor service? * How does this affect upgrades? Third-party drivers could be updated independently from this change, and care must be taken not to break backwards-compatibility within our Driver API. Nova driver impact ------------------ Chances are, if this change affects the REST or Driver APIs, it will also affect the Nova driver in some way. If this requires a functional change in Nova, chances are the Nova team will require a spec to discuss the changes to their project as well. Provide a link to that here, or a justification for why that is not needed. Questions which need to be addressed in this section include: * What is the impact on Nova? * If this change is enabling new functionality exposed via Nova, this section should cite the relevant components within other Nova drivers that already implement this. * Ironic and Nova services must be upgradable independently. If the change affects existing functionality of the nova.virt.ironic driver, how will an upgrade be performed? How will it be tested? Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or credentials? * Does this change affect the accessibility of hardware managed by Ironic? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API and client, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Will this require changes in the Horizon panel, or any other OpenStack project? Scalability impact ------------------ Describe any potential scalability impact on the system, for example any increase in network, RPC, or database traffic, or whether the feature requires synchronization across multiple services. Examples of things to consider here include: * Additional network calls to internal or external services. * Additional disk or network traffic that will be required by the feature. * Any change in the number of physical nodes which can be managed by each conductor service. Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A periodic task might look like a small addition, but all periodic tasks run in a single thread so a periodic task that takes a long time to run will have an effect on the timing of other periodic tasks. * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impact on performance. * Calls which result in one or more database queries (whether in the api or conductor services) can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any TaskManager locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? * How will the new code be affected if the hash ring rebalances while it is running? Other deployer impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example, a flag that other hardware drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values appropriate for production? Provide an explanation of why these defaults are reasonable. * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after it's merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change adds a new service that deployers will be required to run, how would it be deployed? Describe the expected topology, for example, what network connectivity the new service would need, what service(s) it would interact with, how many should run relative to the size of the deployment, and so on. * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we were to change the directory that PXE boot files were stored in, how would we update existing boot files created before the change landed? Would we require deployers to manually move them? Is there a special case in the code, which would be removed after some deprecation period? Would we require operators to delete and recreate all instances in order to perform the upgrade? Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other drivers would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in Ironic, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Ironic, document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? * Does this feature target specific hardware? If so, is it a common standard (eg IPMI) or a vendor-specific implementation (eg iLO)? Testing ======= Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc)? Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== Care must be taken to support our users by not breaking backwards compatibility with either REST API or Driver API changes. * If your proposal includes any changes to the REST API, describe how existing clients will continue to function when interacting with an upgraded API server. * If your proposal includes any changes to the Driver API, describe how existing driver implementations will continue to function when loaded by a conductor running with the new driver base class. * Describe what testing you will be adding to ensure that backwards compatibility is maintained. * If deprecating an existing feature or API, describe the deprecation plan, and for how long compatibility will be maintained. Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

commit_message:
Adds lbaas support to horizon

This adds neutron-lbaas-dashboard to the openstack-dashboard.

Change-Id: Ieec40d24ff771ca571dc7383f62fd58ebc420c8c
Closes-Bug:1592446
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/28/349728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RUN git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas-dashboard \ && cd neutron-lbaas-dashboard \ && git checkout stable/mitaka \ && python setup.py install \ && chown horizon:horizon build/lib/neutron_lbaas_dashboard/enabled/_1481_project_ng_loadbalancersv2_panel.py \ && cp build/lib/neutron_lbaas_dashboard/enabled/_1481_project_ng_loadbalancersv2_panel.py /usr/share/openstack-dashboard/openstack_dashboard/local/enabled \ && cd /usr/share/openstack-dashboard \ && ./manage.py collectstatic --noinput \ && ./manage.py compress

subject: go: make container timeout configurable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-17 16:32:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/96e1cdc3b683abc30bed149f0a70358dc8756189', 'message': "go: make container timeout configurable

Add 3 config options from the swift object server around timing out
container updates.

container_update_timeout sets how long it waits for a container
update before returning to the user and continuing the update
asynchronously.  This should just be set high enough that users
generally get a consistent view of containers.

conn_timeout sets how long it should wait for the TCP connect to
happen.

node_timeout sets how long it should give the request to succeed.

conn_timeout and node_timeout are defaulted to higher than swift's,
since container_update_timeout obviates the need for them to be
super aggressive.

Change-Id: I7220a909c1b92411e499fd00fcffd68be6733866
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-27 20:43:26.000000000', 'files': ['go/objectserver/main.go', 'go/hummingbird/conf_test.go', 'go/hummingbird/conf.go', 'go/objectserver/update.go'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/8fc16fccff78bbe864131aa0423069897c375cca', 'message': "go: make container timeout configurable

Add 3 config options from the swift object server around timing out
container updates.

container_update_timeout sets how long it waits for a container
update before returning to the user and continuing the update
asynchronously.  This should just be set high enough that users
generally get a consistent view of containers.

conn_timeout sets how long it should wait for the TCP connect to
happen.

node_timeout sets how long it should give the request to succeed.

conn_timeout and node_timeout are defaulted to higher than swift's,
since container_update_timeout obviates the need for them to be
super aggressive.

Change-Id: I7220a909c1b92411e499fd00fcffd68be6733866
"}]
commit_message:
go: make container timeout configurable

Add 3 config options from the swift object server around timing out
container updates.

container_update_timeout sets how long it waits for a container
update before returning to the user and continuing the update
asynchronously.  This should just be set high enough that users
generally get a consistent view of containers.

conn_timeout sets how long it should wait for the TCP connect to
happen.

node_timeout sets how long it should give the request to succeed.

conn_timeout and node_timeout are defaulted to higher than swift's,
since container_update_timeout obviates the need for them to be
super aggressive.

Change-Id: I7220a909c1b92411e499fd00fcffd68be6733866

commit_message:
Use the most up-to-date lxc package when on 1404

This change updates the lxc package to use the lxc2 package
instead. This change will ensure we're getting a more updated
version of lxc on trusty than the standard package name provides
by default.

Change-Id: I283e2d3ce2c3441dd0f5f17163421fcf25988880
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Disable tripleo-test-cloud-rh1 until we have AFS mirrors"

mirror.regionone.tripleo-test-cloud-rh1.openstack.org is now online
and provisioned by puppetmaster.openstack.org.

This reverts commit 29c27d8b1ecc70901e1672a725dd38e2b8042897.

commit_message:
Implement new heartbeat for AgentDeploy

Refactor heartbeat and related calls to a new AgentDeployMixin used
in AgentDeploy, ISCSIDeploy and BaseAgentVendor.

Also removes excessive passing of kwargs to where they are not used.
It has a potential of breaking out-of-tree drivers, but it also greatly
simplifies tracking how values are passed during deployment.

Also made several methods just functions.

Change-Id: I56c728c13b06f1aea0baeec0dddc7ba160a7a211
Partial-Bug: #1570841

added_lines: def _cleaning_reboot(task): """Reboots a node out of band after a clean step that requires it. If an agent clean step has 'reboot_requested': True, reboots the node when the step is completed. Will put the node in CLEANFAIL if the node cannot be rebooted. :param task: a TaskManager instance """ try: manager_utils.node_power_action(task, states.REBOOT) except Exception as e: msg = (_('Reboot requested by clean step %(step)s failed for ' 'node %(node)s: %(err)s') % {'step': task.node.clean_step, 'node': task.node.uuid, 'err': e}) LOG.error(msg) # do not set cleaning_reboot if we didn't reboot manager_utils.cleaning_error_handler(task, msg) return # Signify that we've rebooted driver_internal_info = task.node.driver_internal_info driver_internal_info['cleaning_reboot'] = True task.node.driver_internal_info = driver_internal_info task.node.save() def _notify_conductor_resume_clean(task): LOG.debug('Sending RPC to conductor to resume cleaning for node %s', task.node.uuid) uuid = task.node.uuid rpc = rpcapi.ConductorAPI() topic = rpc.get_topic_for(task.node) # Need to release the lock to let the conductor take it task.release_resources() rpc.continue_node_clean(task.context, uuid, topic=topic) class AgentDeployMixin(object): """Mixin with deploy methods.""" _notify_conductor_resume_clean(task) _notify_conductor_resume_clean(task) _cleaning_reboot(task) _notify_conductor_resume_clean(task) def heartbeat(self, task, callback_url): """Process a heartbeat. :param task: task to work with. :param callback_url: agent HTTP API URL. driver_internal_info['agent_url'] = callback_url self.continue_deploy(task) self.reboot_to_instance(task) _notify_conductor_resume_clean(task) self.continue_cleaning(task) class BaseAgentVendor(base.VendorInterface, AgentDeployMixin): def __init__(self): self.supported_payload_versions = ['2'] self._client = _get_client() def continue_deploy(self, task, **kwargs): """Continues the deployment of baremetal node. This method continues the deployment of the baremetal node after the ramdisk have been booted. :param task: a TaskManager instance """ pass def deploy_has_started(self, task): """Check if the deployment has started already. :returns: True if the deploy has started, False otherwise. """ pass def deploy_is_done(self, task): """Check if the deployment is already completed. :returns: True if the deployment is completed. False otherwise """ pass def reboot_to_instance(self, task, **kwargs): """Method invoked after the deployment is completed. :param task: a TaskManager instance """ pass def get_properties(self): """Return the properties of the interface. :returns: dictionary of <property name>:<property description> entries. """ return VENDOR_PROPERTIES def validate(self, task, method, **kwargs): """Validate the driver-specific Node deployment info. No validation necessary. :param task: a TaskManager instance :param method: method to be validated """ pass def driver_validate(self, method, **kwargs): """Validate the driver deployment info. :param method: method to be validated. """ version = kwargs.get('version') if not version: raise exception.MissingParameterValue(_('Missing parameter ' 'version')) if version not in self.supported_payload_versions: raise exception.InvalidParameterValue(_('Unknown lookup ' 'payload version: %s') % version) @base.passthru(['POST']) @task_manager.require_exclusive_lock def pasthru_heartbeat(self, task, **kwargs): """Method for agent to periodically check in. The agent should be sending its agent_url (so Ironic can talk back) as a kwarg. kwargs should have the following format:: { 'agent_url': 'http://AGENT_HOST:AGENT_PORT' } AGENT_PORT defaults to 9999. """ try: callback_url = kwargs['agent_url'] except KeyError: raise exception.MissingParameterValue(_('For heartbeat operation, ' '"agent_url" must be ' 'specified.')) self.heartbeat(task, callback_url)

commit_message:
go: direct client concurrency

Fix up the concurrency in firstResponse/quorumResponse, because
there's a bug in it and also I'm better at it now.

Change-Id: Ib438d747e6f0a0783e2748a0681ab7c3d56bf52f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/32/341632/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "math" // this is based on swift's best_response function. statusCodes := make(chan int) cancel := make(chan struct{}) defer close(cancel) for _, req := range reqs { go func(req *http.Request) { status := 500 if resp, err := c.client.Do(req); err == nil { status = resp.StatusCode } select { case statusCodes <- status: case <-cancel: } }(req) } quorum := int(math.Ceil(float64(len(reqs)) / 2.0)) responseClasses := []int{0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0} for status := range statusCodes { class := status / 100 if class <= 5 { responseClasses[class]++ if responseClasses[class] >= quorum { return status } } } return 503 } func (c *ProxyDirectClient) firstResponse(reqs ...*http.Request) (resp *http.Response) { defer close(resps) cancel := make(chan struct{}) defer close(cancel) for _, req := range reqs { req.Cancel = cancel go func(req *http.Request) { case <-cancel: }(req) select { case <-time.After(time.Second): case resp = <-resps: if resp.StatusCode/100 == 2 { return } } } return
deleted_lines: var requestCount int var done []chan int for _, req := range reqs { donech := make(chan int) done = append(done, donech) go func(client *http.Client, req *http.Request, done chan int) { resp, err := client.Do(req) if err != nil { done <- 500 } else { done <- resp.StatusCode } }(c.client, req, donech) requestCount += 1 } var responses []int quorum := (requestCount / 2) + 1 for chanIndex, d := range done { responses = append(responses, <-d) for statusRange := 200; statusRange <= 400; statusRange += 100 { rangeCount := 0 for _, response := range responses { if response >= statusRange && response < (statusRange+100) { rangeCount += 1 if rangeCount >= quorum { go func() { // wait for any remaining connections to finish for i := chanIndex + 1; i < len(done); i++ { <-(done[i]) } }() return response } } } } } return 500 } func (c *ProxyDirectClient) firstResponse(reqs ...*http.Request) *http.Response { ticker := time.NewTicker(time.Second) defer func() { close(resps) ticker.Stop() }() for _, req := range reqs { go func() { } else if resp.StatusCode/100 != 2 { resp.Body.Close() resp = nil return default: }() select { case <-ticker.C: case resp := <-resps: if resp != nil { return resp } } } return nil

commit_message:
go: set nodelay on repconn

Make sure repconn messages don't suffer nagle delays.
Use bigger buffers to make sure we make efficient use of packets.

I'd like to just use tcp_cork, but it's not exposed very well in go.

Change-Id: Id66c37eb877801706992ccc69d3801e0f7efd716

commit_message:
go: time out flock differently

Use channels and timers to time out a blocking flock, rather than
non-blocking + polling.

Change-Id: Idd7d5d035a5ccf1c609bbd79575ded1e896a3f07

added_lines: func TestLockPath(t *testing.T) { tempDir, err := ioutil.TempDir("", "") defer os.RemoveAll(tempDir) require.Nil(t, err) c := make(chan bool) go func() { f, err := LockPath(tempDir, time.Millisecond) c <- true require.Nil(t, err) require.NotNil(t, f) time.Sleep(time.Second) f.Close() }() <-c f, err := LockPath(tempDir, time.Millisecond) require.Nil(t, f) require.NotNil(t, err) }

commit_message:
Add docs about microversion testing in Tempest

As discussed at the newton midcycle and in the dev
mailing list:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-July/099860.html

We should add a Tempest test for any microversion that
changes the response schema so we have coverage in Tempest
and also so we don't have to fill large gaps in coverage
in Tempest when adding other unrelated tests.

Change-Id: Ie7cfe7ee857caf630d4380cf673ae208842fbc00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/346080/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * If the microversion changes the response schema, a new schema and test for the microversoin must be added to Tempest.

commit_message:
Filter duplicate DHCP ACLs

If a port has multiple fixed IPs on the same subnet, duplicate
DHCP ACLs will be generated. This patch set filters out the
duplicate ACLs.

Change-Id: Id404c13703cb77736d0bf995805a595576e9b7ed

commit_message:
Clear stale SegmentHostMapping when sync ovn sb db

When sync ovn sb db with neutron, compare the records in neutron and
information in ovn sb db. And then clear the stale data, udpate
existing data and add new data in neutron db.

Change-Id: Icb740af5613bb87577f19df98e8f578a3e5003f8
Partially-implements: blueprint routed-networks

commit_message:
Make Aggregate.save work with the API db

Aggregate.save now updates aggregates if they
are located in the api db.

blueprint cells-aggregate-api-db

Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I6066857a421bfe489ae70f0e22f338c434195bf9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/305466/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _aggregate_update_to_db(context, aggregate_id, values): aggregate = Aggregate._aggregate_get_from_db(context, aggregate_id) set_delete = True if "availability_zone" in values: az = values.pop('availability_zone') if 'metadata' not in values: values['metadata'] = {'availability_zone': az} set_delete = False else: values['metadata']['availability_zone'] = az metadata = values.get('metadata') if metadata is not None: Aggregate._metadata_add_to_db(context, aggregate_id, values.pop('metadata'), set_delete=set_delete) aggregate.update(values) try: aggregate.save(context.session) except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: raise exception.AggregateNameExists(aggregate_name=aggregate.name) return Aggregate._aggregate_get_from_db(context, aggregate_id) @db_api.api_context_manager.writer db_aggregate = None if self.in_api: db_aggregate = Aggregate._aggregate_update_to_db( self._context, self.id, updates) else: db_aggregate = db.aggregate_update(self._context, self.id, updates)

commit_message:
Remove duplicate 'delete volume' option  on launch instance

The "delete volume on instance delete" option was being displayed
twice when the boot source was volume or volume snapshots, and
once when the boot source was instance snapshot. This is because when
the option was being created for an image, the option was
duplicated onto every other source. This patch stops the option
from being replicated.

Closes-Bug: #1607976

Change-Id: I89f38041822e078bf4e0ceffebd33e2178c7a53e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/18/349618/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Constraint to prevent duplicate endpoints

Prevent the creation of endpoints with duplicate combination of
service_id, region_id and interface by creating a unique constraint
in endpoint table.
Some tests that created duplicated entries were modified to comply
with this new constraint.
This patch also fixes the new_endpoint_ref helper method that didn't
include the 'enabled' attribute

Co-Authored-By: Henrique Truta <henrique@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>

Change-Id: I7bd44287953dc00d04396aeb18480c4d6aa6dc2d
Closes-Bug: #1376937

commit_message:
Enable in-process func tests to optionally use encryption

Running functional tests in the in-process mode uses
the default value for the pipeline.  This patch adds support
to specify the SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS_CONF_LOADER variable
to point to a labeled function that changes the proxy
configuration for the functional test.

The patch also adds a new tox environment
func-in-process-encryption
which runs with the environment variable
SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS_CONF_LOADER=encryption

The motivation for this change is to put support in place for an
upstream CI job that will functionally test using encryption
middleware in the pipeline.  The gate job is proposed at:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/348292/

Change-Id: I15c4b20f1d2be57ae21c69c614f6a9579145bee9

commit_message:
Fix the provision playbook

There was a missing list item there, that causes the rebuild inventory
role to not get called. This caused issues with the rest of the
playbooks running as root on the virthost.

Change-Id: I152764b4c55ef7dbb9d71f0f37c08e9f904e2254
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/64/349564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Initialise oslo.privsep early in main
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-21 07:03:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/2d82b4857ce3942f50840dcd39a22d04c685bf9c', 'message': 'Initialise oslo.privsep early in main

Any process using oslo.privsep should now initialise the library before
first use with things like the rootwrap command to use.

This should be done near the top of main() in any command that expects
to make privileged calls via oslo.privsep (eg: cinder-volume, and not
cinder-api).

See I3ea73e16b07a870629e7d69e897f2524d7068ae8 for the corresponding
change in oslo.privsep.

Change-Id: Id9652ccf001a707fbd59e277c36817bd6d58e7b3
Closes-Bug: #1592043
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-07 02:54:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1b90c506a72f7821368842debd6b57c849a5f248', 'message': 'Initialise oslo.privsep early in main

Any process using oslo.privsep should now initialise the library before
first use with things like the rootwrap command to use.

This should be done near the top of main() in any command that expects
to make privileged calls via oslo.privsep (eg: cinder-volume, and not
cinder-api).

commit_message:
Initialise oslo.privsep early in main

Any process using oslo.privsep should now initialise the library before
first use with things like the rootwrap command to use.

This should be done near the top of main() in any command that expects
to make privileged calls via oslo.privsep (eg: cinder-volume, and not
cinder-api).

See I3ea73e16b07a870629e7d69e897f2524d7068ae8 for the corresponding
change in oslo.privsep.

Change-Id: Id9652ccf001a707fbd59e277c36817bd6d58e7b3
Closes-Bug: #1592043

commit_message:
Make certs databag optional

This provides an attribute which allows users to optionally disable using the
internal certs databag for SSL certificates. The use case is for people who are
using other external methods (such as the certificates cookbook) to manage
certificates.

Change-Id: Ib7c578135db74675bd4c5a0da13f053f6474e0f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-dashboard refs/changes/15/349615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'does not create certs if certs data bag is disabled' do node.set['openstack']['dashboard']['ssl']['use_data_bag'] = false node.set['openstack']['dashboard']['ssl']['chain'] = 'horizon-chain.pem' expect(chef_run).not_to create_file('/etc/ssl/certs/horizon.pem') expect(chef_run).not_to create_file('/etc/ssl/certs/horizon.key') expect(chef_run).not_to create_file('/etc/ssl/certs/horizon-chain.pem') end

commit_message:
Add the languagepack delete functionality to the dashboard

The dashboard plugin currently does not support the option to delete a
selected languagepack. This patch adds this option to the dashboard
plugin.

Also, here is a link to a screenchot of what the page looks like before
confirming the delete: http://pasteboard.co/HU1vtWlb.png, and after
confirming the delete: http://pasteboard.co/HT6AoO5g.png

Change-Id: I6d6a1c940c35262b2b2531026a3b82a74e47b69e
Closes-Bug: #1600616

added_lines: from solumdashboard.api.client import client as solumclient class DeleteLanguagepack(tables.BatchAction): name = "delete" verbose_name = _("Delete Languagepack") classes = ("btn-terminate", "btn-danger") action_present = _("Delete") action_past = _("Deleted") data_type_singular = _("Languagepack") data_type_plural = _("Languagepacks") def allowed(self, request, template): return True def action(self, request, languagepack_id): solum = solumclient(request) solum.languagepacks.delete(lp_id=languagepack_id) table_actions = (DeleteLanguagepack) row_actions = (ViewLanguagepack, DeleteLanguagepack)

commit_message:
Add the languagepack show and log functionality to the dashboard

The dashboard plugin currently does not support the option to show the
details and logs for a selected languagepack. This patch adds this option
to the dashboard plugin.

Also, here is a link to a screenchot of what the page looks like:
http://pasteboard.co/HR1zlMgT.png

Change-Id: I4f9f6facf8837b374a0d72d657358cc7a88abb1e
Closes-Bug: #1599566

commit_message:
Fix package setup configuration

This change fixes the scenario where performing a package
install (e.g. pip) was failing because the package config
in setup.cfg was causing the egg to be generated incorrectly.

Change-Id: I416fb19448ec53734a42e88de750556b62edf724

Transition default VIM to API and DB operation

Set the default-vim in the tacker-db and provide
API to manage it.

commit_message:
Add the 'min' param to IntOpts where applicable

It was pointed out [0] that any IntOpt with a logical minimum value
should have that specified by including the 'min=' parameter in the
option definition. As that patch was concerned with the help text for
options, it was felt that a separate follow-up patch would be better for
adding these parameters.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/281901/7/nova/conf/network.py@259

Blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I0dbef37736f72401268f3036f77f35a4bbf2b5b7

commit_message:
Mention proxy API deprecation microversion in api-ref

Proxy APIs are deprecated in microversion 2.36 which means
all proxy APIs will return 404 after 2.35 version.

It will be nice to mention that explicitly in api-ref too.

Partially implements blueprint deprecate-api-proxies

Change-Id: Iad210d215fb98bc247f049b23b97d8d7d4265c82

commit_message:
PCI-DSS Limit password changes per day

This patch limits the number of times a user can change their password
(self service) within a 24 hour period. This can be used to deter users
from changing their passwwords repeatedly in order to wipe out their
password history and reuse an old password.

Change-Id: Id84a4effd22a19a50f15572dd70b777321afad9b
Partially-implements: blueprint pci-dss
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/15/348915/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class PasswordChangeLimitTests(test_backend_sql.SqlTests): def setUp(self): super(PasswordChangeLimitTests, self).setUp() self.max_limit = 3 password_change_limit_per_day=self.max_limit)
deleted_lines: import fixtures from oslo_log import log class MinimumPasswordAgeTests(test_backend_sql.SqlTests): def setUp(self): super(MinimumPasswordAgeTests, self).setUp() self.min_age_days = 1 minimum_password_age=self.min_age_days) self.log_info = self.useFixture(fixtures.FakeLogger(level=log.ERROR)) self.password = uuid.uuid4().hex self.new_password = uuid.uuid4().hex self.user = self._create_new_user(self.password) def test_user_cannot_change_password_before_min_age(self): # test user cannot change password before min age self.assertRaises(exception.PasswordValidationError, self.identity_api.change_password, self.make_request(), user_id=self.user['id'], original_password=self.password, new_password=self.new_password) def test_user_can_change_password_after_min_age(self): # set password_created_at so that the min age has past password_created_at = ( datetime.datetime.utcnow() - datetime.timedelta(days=self.min_age_days + 1)) self._update_user(self.user['id'], password_created_at) # test that the user can change their password self.identity_api.change_password(self.make_request(), user_id=self.user['id'], original_password=self.password, new_password=self.new_password) # authenticate with the new passowrd self.identity_api.authenticate(self.make_request(), user_id=self.user['id'], password=self.new_password) def test_password_expires_days_less_than_min_password_age_error(self): # set password_expires_days < minimum_password_age self.config_fixture.config( group='security_compliance', password_expires_days=90) self.config_fixture.config( group='security_compliance', minimum_password_age=91) # change password; test for exception and log self.assertRaises(exception.PasswordValidationError, self.identity_api.change_password, self.make_request(), user_id=self.user['id'], original_password=self.password, new_password=self.new_password) self.assertIn('Unable to validate the minimum password age', self.log_info.output) def _create_new_user(self, password): user = { 'name': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'domain_id': CONF.identity.default_domain_id, 'enabled': True, 'password': password } return self.identity_api.create_user(user) def _update_user(self, user_id, password_create_at): with sql.session_for_write() as session: user_ref = session.query(model.User).get(user_id) user_ref.password_ref.created_at = password_create_at

commit_message:
Make Dependency metadata optional

Currently X-Object-Meta-Storlet-Dependency is one of the required
metadata for storlet object file, but not all storlet applications
require dependencies.

This patch makes that metadata optional, and let us upload a storlet
object without adding an empty metadata to it.

Change-Id: I3514bd5447bab29dd906831d1d76c2b2f6851bd6

added_lines: options = {'storlet_main': 'org.openstack.storlet.Storlet'} dsreq = DockerStorletRequest(storlet_id, params, metadata, iter(StringIO()), options=options) self.assertEqual(metadata, dsreq.user_metadata) self.assertEqual(params, dsreq.params) self.assertEqual('Storlet-1.0.jar', dsreq.storlet_id) self.assertEqual('org.openstack.storlet.Storlet', dsreq.storlet_main) self.assertEqual([], dsreq.dependencies) # correct name and headers w/ dependency # correct name and headers w/o dependency obj = 'storlet-1.0.jar' params = {'Language': 'java', 'Interface-Version': '1.0', 'Object-Metadata': 'no', 'Main': 'path.to.storlet.class'} StorletGatewayDocker.validate_storlet_registration(params, obj)

commit_message:
Fix updating allocation_pools on subnet update

Reference IPAM driver skipped subnet_update processing
if allocation_pools in subnet request are blank.

Built-in ipam implementation allows to update allocation pools
to blank value (i.e. clean up allocation pools for subnet).
To make Reference ipam driver consistent with built-in ipam
implementation allocation_pool check was removed.

Included UT to verify that allocation pools can be updated to blank
value now.

Change-Id: I0654e46d4bc60f6cf51ffddeead238dd4f064db2
Closes-Bug: #1605277
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/98/345498/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set timeout value in urllib3.poolmanager.PoolManager

If timeout is not set in urllib3.poolmanager.PoolManager, it will
use "Python's default timeout for sockets", but if "timeout for
sockets" is not set, the timeout will be infinite(will not timeout).
so this is intented to set timeout value in urllib3.poolmanager.
PoolManager to avoid infinite timeout.

Change-Id: Ic035fdb93734c926b26b33feb610e0977e48c646
Closes-Bug: #1558931

commit_message:
CORS test now operates on test_resp instead of init_resp

Since send_init_request is now part of BTC, it no longer makes sense for the
CORS test to operate on init_request. Furthermore, the CORS test currently
throws an exception in master.

Change-Id: I21c144bedeafb3ab5cbffe33768fe6cba489b70e

commit_message:
OS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN must be an ID

Fix the documentation to indicate that the value
of OS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN must be the domain ID. A
domain name is not valid here

Change-Id: Id6d42aa10ef346fa5124ef841c5ce408e34d6424

commit_message:
Address low-hanging TODO items

This change removes the return_netmask function, which was used to
provide an interface to the old inventory schema prior to Kilo. This is
no longer supported, so the function can be removed. The related
'old_netmask' variable was also deleted as it served no other purpose.

The 'old_address' variable was formerly constructed using either the
queue name (such as container or storage) that the IP address came from,
or with the name of the network interface. The queue name approach is
most recent, so the conditional for choosing between them was removed in
favor of simply using the queue name.

Also removed was a line for removing network address information from
the top level of the host_var dictionary. This housekeeping is no longer
necessary.

Other TODOs remain, but this change was purposefully kept small as the
remaining changes are not as straightforward and may have broader
impact.

Change-Id: I5010107fdae077ff133e01c9369ddad28852637f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/98/329098/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: old_address = '%s_address' % q_name network['netmask'] = netmask network['netmask'] = netmask
deleted_lines: def return_netmask(): """Return the netmask for a container.""" # TODO(cloudnull) After a few releases this conditional should be # simplified. The container address checking that is ssh address # is only being done to support old inventory. _old_netmask = container.get(old_netmask) if _old_netmask: return container.pop(old_netmask) elif netmask: return netmask # TODO(cloudnull) after a few releases this should be removed. if q_name: old_address = '%s_address' % q_name else: old_address = '%s_address' % interface # TODO(cloudnull) after a few releases this should be removed. # This removes the old container network value that now serves purpose. container.pop('container_network', None) network['netmask'] = return_netmask() network['netmask'] = return_netmask()

commit_message:
Switch to layered charm

This charm is a thin layer sitting on top of the layer-ceph-mon
layer that is being built in parallel.

Change-Id: I49d640c5781727d7a7e19d97040da2bcc09c4c3f

See the # GNU Lesser General Public License for more details. # # You should have received a copy of the GNU Lesser General Public License # along with charm-helpers. If not, see <http://www.gnu.org/licenses/>. import os import re import subprocess from charmhelpers.core.hookenv import ( log, INFO, ) from charmhelpers.contrib.hardening.audits.file import ( FilePermissionAudit, DirectoryPermissionAudit, NoReadWriteForOther, TemplatedFile, ) from charmhelpers.contrib.hardening.audits.apache import DisabledModuleAudit from charmhelpers.contrib.hardening.apache import TEMPLATES_DIR from charmhelpers.contrib.hardening import utils def get_audits(): """Get Apache hardening config audits. :returns: dictionary of audits """ if subprocess.call(['which', 'apache2'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE) != 0: log("Apache server does not appear to be installed on this node - " "skipping apache hardening", level=INFO) return [] context = ApacheConfContext() settings = utils.get_settings('apache') audits = [ FilePermissionAudit(paths='/etc/apache2/apache2.conf', user='root', group='root', mode=0o0640), TemplatedFile(os.path.join(settings['common']['apache_dir'], 'mods-available/alias.conf'), context, TEMPLATES_DIR, mode=0o0755, user='root', service_actions=[{'service': 'apache2', 'actions': ['restart']}]), TemplatedFile(os.path.join(settings['common']['apache_dir'], 'conf-enabled/hardening.conf'), context, TEMPLATES_DIR, mode=0o0640, user='root', service_actions=[{'service': 'apache2', 'actions': ['restart']}]), DirectoryPermissionAudit(settings['common']['apache_dir'], user='root', group='root', mode=0o640), DisabledModuleAudit(settings['hardening']['modules_to_disable']), NoReadWriteForOther(settings['common']['apache_dir']), ] return audits class ApacheConfContext(object): """Defines the set of key/value pairs to set in a apache config file. This context, when called, will return a dictionary containing the key/value pairs of setting to specify in the /etc/apache/conf-enabled/hardening.conf file. """ def __call__(self): settings = utils.get_settings('apache') ctxt = settings['hardening'] out = subprocess.check_output(['apache2', '-v']) ctxt['apache_version'] = re.search(r'.+version: Apache/(.+?)\s.+', out).group(1) ctxt['apache_icondir'] = '/usr/share/apache2/icons/' ctxt['traceenable'] = settings['hardening']['traceenable'] return ctxt

added_lines: CREATE PROJECTION Measurements_time_order_rep_MonMetrics /*+createtype(D)*/ ( definition_dimensions_id ENCODING RLE, time_stamp ENCODING COMMONDELTA_COMP, value ENCODING AUTO, value_meta ENCODING AUTO ) AS SELECT definition_dimensions_id, time_stamp, value, value_meta FROM MonMetrics.Measurements ORDER BY time_stamp, definition_dimensions_id UNSEGMENTED ALL NODES;
