commit_message:
Add dib element to generate logical volumes

Encapsulate the functionality of logical volume creation
on an element, to be able to build images with logical
volumes embedded.

Change-Id: I2cd9efda76115fa6db66a5b247f0f3ce19c729fc

commit_message:
Keep localrc in CLI Sahara job

We need to add additional configuration for devstack (file upload).
Also remove the post hook, not useful anymore after the tests are
changed into real Tempest tests.

Change-Id: If971b8e8a677a74a30869f28b777dce40807e280
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/00/348800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export KEEP_LOCALRC=1

subject: Set up stable/newton temporary ACLs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-25 10:43:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/180acdf93019aa06f294b4b1d02e21c27ba7c1f5', 'message': "Set up stable/newton temporary ACLs

Set up a temporary ACL rule for handling the upcoming
stable/newton release branches, for milestone-driven projects
which will go through a release candidate phase.

The $project-release-branch groups will have 'Release Managers'
as its initial member and admin. We'll add PTLs and release
liaisons to the groups pre-release, then add the stable maintenance
team at release time. Then the temporary ACLs will be removed.

This process lets us handle the transition from release branch to
stable branch gracefully and without too much sync points between
infra and release teams.

commit_message:
Set up stable/newton temporary ACLs

Set up a temporary ACL rule for handling the upcoming
stable/newton release branches, for milestone-driven projects
which will go through a release candidate phase.

The $project-release-branch groups will have 'Release Managers'
as its initial member and admin. We'll add PTLs and release
liaisons to the groups pre-release, then add the stable maintenance
team at release time. Then the temporary ACLs will be removed.

This process lets us handle the transition from release branch to
stable branch gracefully and without too much sync points between
infra and release teams.

Change-Id: I16ab679ee7b1f9018299659ecdc03b089600f701

commit_message:
Swap neutron/nova-net multinode full jobs in nova check queue

This moves the neutron multinode job into nova's check queue
from experimental and the nova-net multinode job from check
to experimental. This is mostly because:

1. Nova broke the neutron multinode job, see:

   If515a90217a8e329d932dcacb357b78081c505c1

2. nova-network is deprecated.

3. The gate-tempest-dsvm-multinode-live-migration job in
   nova's check queue runs nova-net so we already have some
   coverage there for a multinode nova-net job (which is really
   what we have the multinode job for in the first place).

Change-Id: I25945171e8d489245690bbe8a68c9aff409d1e8b

commit_message:
Switch default partition type to gpt

Systems with >2TB 'disks' are becoming more commonplace on servers
with embedded raid arrays etc. Switch default partition type to gpt
from msdos when we find ourselves with a larger disk.

Co-Authored-By: Tom Hancock <tom.hancock@hp.com>

Change-Id: I9ab39ad7692df411a9a1c6998c0f701f9ee8e905
Closes-Bug: #1298362
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-lib refs/changes/56/225556/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Matching different disk partition formats # # msdos # /dev/sda:976762MiB:scsi:512:4096:msdos:ATA MTFDDAK1T0MAY-1A; # 1:1.00MiB:501MiB:500MiB:ext4::boot # # gpt # /dev/sda:976762MiB:scsi:512:4096:gpt:ATA MTFDDAK1T0MAY-1A; # 1:1MiB:538MiB:537MiB:fat32:EFI System Partition:boot; # 2:538MB:794MB:256MB:ext2::; # 3:794MB:1024GB:1023GB:::lvm; _LABELS_DICT = {'gpt': {'fields': ('number', 'start', 'end', 'size', 'filesystem', 'name', 'flags'), 're': re.compile(r"^(\d+):([\d\.]+)MiB:" "([\d\.]+)MiB:([\d\.]+)MiB:" "(\w*):(\w*):(\w*)")}, 'msdos': {'fields': ('number', 'start', 'end', 'size', 'filesystem', 'flags'), 're': re.compile(r"^(\d+):([\d\.]+)MiB:" "([\d\.]+)MiB:([\d\.]+)MiB:" "(\w*)::(\w*)")}} _MAX_DISK_FOR_MBR = 1907000 # 2Tb = 1.907x10^6 Mebibytes (MiB) lines = [line for line in output.split('\n') if line.strip()][1:] label_type = lines[0].split(':')[5] if label_type not in _LABELS_DICT: LOG.warn(_LW("Partition information from parted for device " "%(device)s shows unsupported label type: %(label)s"), dict(device=device, label=label_type)) return result fields = _LABELS_DICT[label_type]['fields'] check_re = _LABELS_DICT[label_type]['re'] for line in lines[1:]: match = check_re.match(line) # Determine the total size of disk, to see if we need to change the # default disk partitioning method to gpt. if root_mb + swap_mb + ephemeral_mb + configdrive_mb > _MAX_DISK_FOR_MBR: default_disk_label = 'gpt' else: default_disk_label = 'msdos' dp = disk_partitioner.DiskPartitioner(dev, disk_label=default_disk_label)
deleted_lines: _PARTED_PRINT_RE = re.compile(r"^(\d+):([\d\.]+)MiB:" "([\d\.]+)MiB:([\d\.]+)MiB:(\w*)::(\w*)") lines = [line for line in output.split('\n') if line.strip()][2:] # Example of line: 1:1.00MiB:501MiB:500MiB:ext4::boot fields = ('number', 'start', 'end', 'size', 'filesystem', 'flags') for line in lines: match = _PARTED_PRINT_RE.match(line) dp = disk_partitioner.DiskPartitioner(dev)

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-04-05 16:41:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f9f51549948c862417a3f2186ca3539327a342a1', 'message': "Add functional tests for nested quotas

Adds functional tests for nested quotas as an alternative
to creating a Tempest test + gate job that would only run
Cinder related quota checks.

NOTE: The QUOTA engine in Cinder is a global variable that lazy loads
the quota driver, so even if we change the config for the quota driver,
we won't reliably change the driver being used (or change it back)
unless the global variables get cleaned up, so using mock instead of
overriding _get_flags to change the quota driver.

Change-Id: Ic9b7ef3c8e4978c1f1fee38a5c2511ba5cbe5559
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-04-05 20:02:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a07f3741ee7f07616cba655f9006c9da857d9ae5', 'message': "Add functional tests for nested quotas

Adds functional tests for nested quotas as an alternative
to creating a Tempest test + gate job that would only run
Cinder related quota checks.

NOTE: The QUOTA engine in Cinder is a global variable that lazy loads
the quota driver, so even if we change the config for the quota driver,
we won't reliably change the driver being used (or change it back)
unless the global variables get cleaned up, so using mock instead of
overriding _get_flags to change the quota driver.

Change-Id: Ic9b7ef3c8e4978c1f1fee38a5c2511ba5cbe5559
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-07-20 18:32:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/dbbcfe6102da5302a2d1a9f46a1af03ae12e2026', 'message': "Add functional tests for nested quotas

Adds functional tests for nested quotas as an alternative
to creating a Tempest test + gate job that would only run
Cinder related quota checks.

NOTE: The QUOTA engine in Cinder is a global variable that lazy loads
the quota driver, so even if we change the config for the quota driver,
we won't reliably change the driver being used (or change it back)
unless the global variables get cleaned up, so using mock instead of
overriding _get_flags to change the quota driver.

commit_message:
Add functional tests for nested quotas

Adds functional tests for nested quotas as an alternative
to creating a Tempest test + gate job that would only run
Cinder related quota checks.

NOTE: The QUOTA engine in Cinder is a global variable that lazy loads
the quota driver, so even if we change the config for the quota driver,
we won't reliably change the driver being used (or change it back)
unless the global variables get cleaned up, so using mock instead of
overriding _get_flags to change the quota driver.

Co-Authored-By: Xinli Guan <xinli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: Ic9b7ef3c8e4978c1f1fee38a5c2511ba5cbe5559

commit_message:
Resolve unittest hang issue

This patch removes suspect decorator patch_no_sleep from VNX unit
test, and set the timeout = 0 when running tests to avoid potential
long running.

Also removed mock.patch of FixedIntervalLoopingCall from the setup
of Huawei unit test to prevent test_replication_driver_enable_success
in test_huawei_drivers.py from hanging.

Change-Id: I5c8efbf9a62e0f5bc39c5341b53f7af4e47c7e81
Partial-Bug: #1578986

commit_message:
Remove array metadata when no items + fix case

Array metadata appends an operator automatically, which
means the value will still contain something and it
doesn't get detected for removal.

In addition, bad APIs like glance v1 will store a property
with mixed case, but then return only lower case when
listing them. However, it will not remove the property
when you request to remove it unless it matches the original
case (sad panda).  So, this patch will reset the proper
casing for properties defined as metadata definitions before
making the request to save the metadata.

Change-Id: I1e5a6fde35b7be6118f21ac46ad0aea088280215
Closes-Bug: 1606988

commit_message:
Explicitly set heat.conf logging_exception_prefix

Gate logs for heat jobs really need to log stack traces with TRACE
instead of ERROR because some traces are being printed by passing
exc_info=True to LOG.info so they are not actual errors.

TRACE should be the default for oslo.log but something in the gate
setup is setting it to ERROR. Setting explicitly here restores the
desired pattern and protects against gate default overrides.

Change-Id: Id85287324fa6dc79d67fb1ed37c3f256d661133e
Closes-Bug: #1606404
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/64/348564/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo -e 'logging_exception_prefix="%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d TRACE %(name)s %(instance)s"\n' >> $localconf

added_lines: %global sname python-barbicanclient Name: {{ 'python-barbicanclient' | py2pkg }} Version: 3.3.0 Release: 0 Summary: Client for the Barbican Key Management API License: {{ 'Apache-2.0' | license }} URL: http://www.openstack.org/%{sname} Source0: https://pypi.python.org/packages/source/p/%{sname}/%{sname}-%{version}.tar.gz BuildArch: noarch BuildRequires: python-devel BuildRequires: {{ 'setuptools' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'Sphinx' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'requests' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'pbr' | py2pkg }} BuildRequires: {{ 'requests-mock' | py2pkg }} >= 0.6.0 BuildRequires: {{ 'mock' | py2pkg }} >= 1.2 BuildRequires: {{ 'testrepository' | py2pkg }} >= 0.0.18 BuildRequires: {{ 'testtools' | py2pkg }} >= 1.4.0 BuildRequires: {{ 'python-keystoneclient' | py2pkg }} >= 1:1.6.0 BuildRequires: {{ 'cliff' | py2pkg }} >= 1.14.0 Requires: {{ 'pbr' | py2pkg }} >= 1.6 Requires: {{ 'argparse' | py2pkg }} Requires: {{ 'PrettyTable' | py2pkg }} >= 0.7 Requires: {{ 'requests' | py2pkg }} >= 2.5.2 Requires: {{ 'setuptools' | py2pkg }} Requires: {{ 'simplejson' | py2pkg }} >= 2.2.0 Requires: {{ 'six' | py2pkg }} >= 1.9.0 Requires: {{ 'python-keystoneclient' | py2pkg }} >= 1:1.6.0 Requires: {{ 'cliff' | py2pkg }} >= 1.14.0 Requires: {{ 'oslo.i18n' | py2pkg }} >= 1.5.0 Requires: {{ 'oslo.serialization' | py2pkg }} >= 1.4.0 Requires: {{ 'oslo.utils' | py2pkg }} >= 2.0.0 %description OpenStack Key Management API client - Python 2.x This is a client for the Barbican Key Management API. This package includes a Python library for accessing the API (the barbicanclient module), and a command-line script (barbican). This package contains the Python 2.x module. %prep %setup -q -n %{name}-%{version} # Remove bundled egg-info rm -rf %{name}.egg-info # Let RPM handle the requirements rm -f {test-,}requirements.txt # Remove the sphinx-build leftovers rm -rf html/.{doctrees,buildinfo} %build %{__python2} setup.py build %install %{__python2} setup.py install --skip-build --root %{buildroot} %check export PYTHONPATH="%{python2_sitearch}:%{python2_sitelib}:%{buildroot}%{python2_sitelib}" export PYTHON="%{__python2} -S" testr init && testr run --parallel %files %doc README.rst LICENSE %{python_sitelib}/python_barbicanclient-%{version}-py?.?.egg-info %{python_sitelib}/barbicanclient %{_bindir}/barbican %changelog

commit_message:
Replace dict.iteritems with six.iteritems to make PY3 compatible

Python3 do not use dict.iteritems, which would raise AttributeError: 'dict'
object has no attribute 'iteritems'.

Change-Id: Ia1c30e40a8e9f15e9fc757716b66aeccf24ea28a
Closes-Bug: #1596124
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/30/334130/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: items = six.iteritems(obj)

commit_message:
Do not try to check for existing snapshots on Windows

There is no code to check for existing snapshots on Windows. Listing
them for that purpose just produces an error condition if the snapshot
does not exist (the common case) and the build aborts.

This patch removes the snapshot listing call from the Windows batch
files; it fixes a regression introduced with commit
3678ef2fa9893468604411ff697361bbd48d1e73.

Closes-Bug: #1606766
Change-Id: I221cabdf5e9948dda81cefdff7c8f3b3ab96817c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/26/347526/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # On Windows, don't test; take snapshots unconditionally if ! WBATCH= vm_snapshot_exists "$vm_name" "$shot_name"; then

subject: Make shutdown command work on Windows
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-26 19:21:17.000000000', 'files': ['labs/osbash/lib/osbash/virtualbox-functions.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/training-labs/commit/fc5f506df91519292bf17dabead19c8e64b29799', 'message': 'Make shutdown command work on Windows

The recently introduced shutdown command did not make it into the
Windows batch files when calling osbash.sh only with the "-w" option
because in that case, vm_is_running would always return false.

This patch drops that check in vm_acpi_shutdown entirely. It is redundant
because every call to vm_acpi_shutdown is made from a location where the
VM is known to run (of course the VM can be stopped in the meantime,
but the removed check just made the window for that race somewhat
smaller without actually eliminating it).

Change-Id: Ia46705b2e9e78d9746a0c14685d724c53bfcdb47
'}]
commit_message:
Make shutdown command work on Windows

The recently introduced shutdown command did not make it into the
Windows batch files when calling osbash.sh only with the "-w" option
because in that case, vm_is_running would always return false.

This patch drops that check in vm_acpi_shutdown entirely. It is redundant
because every call to vm_acpi_shutdown is made from a location where the
VM is known to run (of course the VM can be stopped in the meantime,
but the removed check just made the window for that race somewhat
smaller without actually eliminating it).

Change-Id: Ia46705b2e9e78d9746a0c14685d724c53bfcdb47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/28/347528/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo -e >&2 "${CStatus:-}ACPI shutdown for VM ${CData:-}\"$vm_name\"${CReset:-}" $VBM controlvm "$vm_name" acpipowerbutton
deleted_lines: if vm_is_running "$vm_name"; then echo -e >&2 "${CStatus:-}ACPI shutdown for VM ${CData:-}\"$vm_name\"${CReset:-}" $VBM controlvm "$vm_name" acpipowerbutton fi

subject: Handle API NotFound exceptions at WSGI level
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-09 16:02:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/2f19505dfded9ce4eaf44015a32afe18497336c6', 'message': 'Handle API NotFound exceptions at WSGI level

Throughout the API code we keep catching NotFound exceptions in their
various forms and converting them to webob.exc.HTTPNotFound exceptions,
but we can leave the WSGI fault handler convert them on its own.

This patch changes current behavior and removes the exception handling
closer to the operation so that those exceptions can be handled at the
WSGI level.

This has the following benefits:

- Reduces code complexity
- Increases code readability
- Provides consistent error responses, as messages are stored on the
  Exceptions.
- Prevents raising errors with only partial information (we have cases
  now that were removing the UUID from the message because they used a
  custom message).  For example: before returned error would be "The
  resource could not be found", and now we raise "Volume type encryption
  for type 4e9e6d23-eed0-426d-b90a-28f87a94b6fe does not exist."
  automatically.
- Reduces workload for the translation team because we remove all
  unnecessary custom messages.

Change-Id: I09f98921fdc2400cc3f6056e59001100abe06920

commit_message:
Handle API NotFound exceptions at WSGI level

Throughout the API code we keep catching NotFound exceptions in their
various forms and converting them to webob.exc.HTTPNotFound exceptions,
but we can leave the WSGI fault handler convert them on its own.

This patch changes current behavior and removes the exception handling
closer to the operation so that those exceptions can be handled at the
WSGI level.

This has the following benefits:

- Reduces code complexity
- Increases code readability
- Provides consistent error responses, as messages are stored on the
  Exceptions.
- Prevents raising errors with only partial information (we have cases
  now that were removing the UUID from the message because they used a
  custom message).  For example: before returned error would be "The
  resource could not be found", and now we raise "Volume type encryption
  for type 4e9e6d23-eed0-426d-b90a-28f87a94b6fe does not exist."
  automatically.
- Reduces workload for the translation team because we remove all
  unnecessary custom messages.

Change-Id: I09f98921fdc2400cc3f6056e59001100abe06920
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/93/314193/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Not found exception will be handled at the wsgi level snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) req.cache_db_snapshot(snapshot) # Not found exception will be handled at the wsgi level snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) self.volume_api.delete_snapshot(context, snapshot) # Not found exception will be handled at the wsgi level volume = self.volume_api.get(context, volume_id) # Not found exception will be handled at the wsgi level snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) self.volume_api.update_snapshot(context, snapshot, update_dict)
deleted_lines: try: snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) req.cache_db_snapshot(snapshot) except exception.NotFound: raise exc.HTTPNotFound() try: snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) self.volume_api.delete_snapshot(context, snapshot) except exception.NotFound: raise exc.HTTPNotFound() try: volume = self.volume_api.get(context, volume_id) except exception.NotFound: raise exc.HTTPNotFound() try: snapshot = self.volume_api.get_snapshot(context, id) self.volume_api.update_snapshot(context, snapshot, update_dict) except exception.NotFound: raise exc.HTTPNotFound()

commit_message:
Remove Networking API files

The Networking APIs will be managed by the networking team
in the networking repo.

Change-Id: Ib3efa8543d575e601503748e30e1ea23026d4b1f

commit_message:
[config-ref] add image format note about Ceph RBD back end

http://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/rbd/qemu-rbd/

backport: mitaka

Change-Id: Ic86b0a3d7851817c420cc7257c42bbd06c33b64f
Closes-Bug: #1356163
(cherry picked from commit 8a94396e1aab75cdafc85b5dc36045885c1a411f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/75/347675/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: You must use only ``raw`` image formats with the Ceph RBD back end.

commit_message:
Remove references to "quota_items"

The config "quota_items" no longer exists, so this removes all references of
"quota_items" from the docs.

Change-Id: I5508696c562d1c6f253756eb8a67b603efb21b51
Closes-Bug: #1600405

commit_message:
Add validate_db_int() method for validation

Added validate_db_int() method to check that given arguments
are of type int and should not exceed maximum value of SQL
integer type i.e., 2 ** 31 - 1.
Raise InputValidationError if argument is invalid.

Related-Bug: #1543937
Change-Id: I6f49bd2fdfe508cd7ff473a716860c4206221202
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/89/306389/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestUtilsValidateDBArguments(test_base.BaseTestCase): def test_validate_db_int_value_in_range(self): result = utils.validate_db_int(test_int=9778) self.assertIsNone(result) def test_validate_db_int_value_out_of_range(self): max_int = (2 ** 31) - 1 res = self.assertRaises(exception.DBDataError, utils.validate_db_int, test_int=2334546144266) msg = ("'%(param)s' value out of range, " "must not exceed %(max)d.") % {"param": "test_int", "max": max_int} self.assertEqual(msg, six.text_type(res.args[0]))

In unittesttools, assertDictEqual() and assertEqual()
are implemented by using '!=' operator. But assertEqual()
can handle dict, list, set and so on. So we just call

Change-Id: I165c7b408fec9afed399c4d0fcdd1bfebca5cd16
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-27 06:26:32.000000000', 'files': ['senlin/tests/unit/profiles/test_nova_server.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/senlin/commit/ad1a604eda39068ea5239398ee6bcd522fb628c6', 'message': "Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()

In unittesttools, assertDictEqual() and assertEqual()

commit_message:
Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()

In unittesttools, assertDictEqual() and assertEqual()
are implemented by using '!=' operator. But assertEqual()
can handle dict, list, set and so on. So we just call
assertEqual() to make the tests simpler.

Change-Id: I165c7b408fec9afed399c4d0fcdd1bfebca5cd16

commit_message:
Correct the wrong reference title and link

The reference link name is "Block Storage Configuration Reference", but
click into the content title is "Block Storage service", this is not
consistent, this patch provide the right title and reference link.


Change-Id: Iee1eb777b5e274ff19b859fb1d312bdfa9fc1922

added_lines: import oslo_messaging as messagingclass HostsNotFound(Exception): pass def get_rpc_info_from_oslo(additional_conf=None): try: return _get_rpc_info_from_transport_url(additional_conf) except (cfg.NoSuchOptError, HostsNotFound): pass return _prepare_rabbit_conf_dict( CONF.oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_userid, CONF.oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_password, additional_conf.topic, additional_conf.host, CONF.oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_host, CONF.oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_port, CONF.oslo_messaging_rabbit.rabbit_virtual_host, ) def _get_rpc_info_from_transport_url(additional_conf): transport_url = CONF.transport_url transport = messaging.TransportURL.parse(CONF, transport_url) if len(transport.hosts) != 1: # TODO(ddeja): Handle multiple hosts. raise HostsNotFound transport_host = transport.hosts[0] if transport.transport in ['rabbit', 'fake']: return _prepare_rabbit_conf_dict( transport_host.username, transport_host.password, additional_conf.topic, additional_conf.host, transport_host.hostname, transport_host.port, transport.virtual_host or '/', ) else: # TODO(ddeja): Implement. raise NotImplementedError def _prepare_rabbit_conf_dict(user_id, password, topic, server_id, host, port, virtual_host): return { 'user_id': user_id, 'password': password, 'topic': topic, 'server_id': server_id, 'host': host, 'port': port, 'virtual_host': virtual_host,

commit_message:
Add PostgreSQL models

Currently extensions/postgresql/service.py uses MySQL's models.
This commit creates PostgreSQL's model and use it.
By introducing PostgreSQL models, we can implement PostgreSQL specific
validation for character_set, password, etc.

Related-Bug: #1513150
Change-Id: Ic5df299cf8525c858fe3757a313701b26264e11c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/99/337399/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from smaug.tests.fullstack import smaug_base from smaug.tests.fullstack import smaug_objects as objects class ProtectablesTest(smaug_base.SmaugBaseTest): """Test Protectables operation """ def test_protectables_get_with_project(self): protectable_type = 'OS::Keystone::Project' res = self.smaug_client.protectables.get(protectable_type) self.assertTrue(len(res.dependent_types)) def test_protectables_list_instances(self): res_list = self.smaug_client.protectables.list_instances( 'OS::Cinder::Volume') before_num = len(res_list) volume1 = self.store(objects.Volume()) volume1.create(1) res_list = self.smaug_client.protectables.list_instances( 'OS::Cinder::Volume') after_num = len(res_list) self.assertEqual(1, after_num - before_num) def test_protectables_get_with_server(self): server_list = self.smaug_client.protectables.list_instances( 'OS::Nova::Server') before_num = len(server_list) server = self.store(objects.Server()) server.create() server_list = self.smaug_client.protectables.list_instances( 'OS::Nova::Server') after_num = len(server_list) self.assertEqual(1, after_num - before_num) def test_protectables_get_with_attach_volume(self): server = self.store(objects.Server()) server.create() volume = self.store(objects.Volume()) volume.create(1) server.attach_volume(volume.id) volume_item = self.cinder_client.volumes.get(volume.id) ins_res = self.smaug_client.protectables.get_instance( 'OS::Nova::Server', volume_item.attachments[0]["server_id"]) self.assertTrue(ins_res.dependent_resources) self.assertEqual('OS::Cinder::Volume', ins_res.dependent_resources[0]["type"]) self.assertEqual(volume.id, ins_res.dependent_resources[0]["id"])

commit_message:
WIP - switch to aodhclient

alarms in Ceilometer is now Aodh service. ceilometerclient is
able to redirect to aodh-api but let's just avoid that and start
using aodhclient.

Change-Id: I35803c0d5f43b214dda7abdcd69a33b4cd0c2646
Co-Authored-By: liusheng <liusheng@huawei.com>

commit_message:
ITRI DISCO cinder backup driver

This commit adds a Cinder backup driver for ITRI DISCO product.

The DISCO backup driver supports the following features:

* Backup any volume from any drivers to DISCO backend
* It will be incremental backup if it is a backup of a DISCO volume
* Restore a backup from DISCO storage system

It also includes the unit tests.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint disco-backup-driver-cinder

Change-Id: Ifea020bb7b47a2d4ba179323a237c4a4d4510d12

"""Test cases to test a DISCO to DISCO backup.""" import copy import mock import time import uuid from cinder import db from cinder import exception from cinder.tests.unit.backup.drivers import disco from cinder.tests.unit import utils as utils from cinder.volume.drivers.disco import disco as disco_driver from cinder.volume.drivers.disco import disco_api class DISCOToDISCOBackupTestCase(disco.TestDISCOBackupDriver): """Test cases for DISCO backup.""" def _create_volume_db_entry(self, id, size): vol = {'id': id, 'size': size, 'status': 'available'} return db.volume_create(self.ctxt, vol)['id'] def _create_backup_db_entry(self, backupid, volid, size, userid=str(uuid.uuid4()), projectid=str(uuid.uuid4())): backup = {'id': backupid, 'size': size, 'volume_id': volid, 'user_id': userid, 'project_id': projectid} return db.backup_create(self.ctxt, backup)['id'] def setUp(self): """Initialise variables and mock functions.""" super(DISCOToDISCOBackupTestCase, self).setUp() self.volume_file = disco.FakeVolumeFile('/dev/dms1234567') # Mock the source volume self.mock_object(db.sqlalchemy.api, 'volume_get', self.get_fake_volume) self.ip_address = '127.0.0.1' self.port = 9898 self.client = disco_api.DISCOAPI(self.ip_address, self.port) self.param = {'backup_id': '1234'} self.start_time = int(time.time()) self.disco_check = disco_driver.DISCOCheck( self.client, self.param, self.start_time, 'backup_detail') self.fake_affect_backup_policy_response = { 'standard': { 'success': {'status': 0, 'result': 'affected the backup policy'}, 'fail': {'status': 1, 'result': 'an error message'}} } self.fake_do_backup_response = { 'standard': { 'success': {'status': 0, 'result': '123'}, 'fail': {'status': 1, 'result': 'an error message'}} } backup_detail_response = { 'status': 0, 'backupDetail': {'backupId': 1234, 'status': 0} } backup_success = copy.deepcopy(backup_detail_response) backup_pending = copy.deepcopy(backup_detail_response) backup_fail = copy.deepcopy(backup_detail_response) backup_response_fail = copy.deepcopy(backup_detail_response) backup_success['backupDetail']['status'] = ( self.DETAIL_OPTIONS['success']) backup_pending['backupDetail']['status'] = ( self.DETAIL_OPTIONS['pending']) backup_fail['backupDetail']['status'] = ( self.DETAIL_OPTIONS['failure']) backup_response_fail['status'] = 1 self.fake_backup_detail_response = { 'backup_detail': { 'success': backup_success, 'fail': backup_fail, 'pending': backup_pending, 'request_fail': backup_response_fail } } self.test_pending = False self.test_pending_count = 0 self.is_disco = True self.affect_bp_response = \ self.fake_affect_backup_policy_response['standard']['success'] self.do_backup_response = \ self.fake_do_backup_response['standard']['success'] self.volume_info = self.volume_info_responses['success'] self.monitor_backup_status = \ self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['success'] def fake_source_volume_type(self, *cmd, **kwargs): """Mock function is_file_disco.""" return self.is_disco def get_volume_information(self, *cmd, **kwargs): """Mock function _get_volume_information.""" return self.volume_info def affect_backup_policy_to_volume(self, *cmd, **kwargs): """Mock function affect backup policy.""" return self.affect_bp_response def do_backup(self, *cmd, **kwargs): """Mock function backup_create.""" return self.do_backup_response def monitor_end_backup(self, *cmd, **kwargs): """Mock function monitor_end_backup.""" if not self.test_pending: return self.monitor_backup_status if self.test_pending_count == 0: self.test_pending_count += 1 return self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['pending'] else: return self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['success'] def backup_disco_to_disco(self): """Test the method to backup a disco volume to a disco backend.""" self.driver.backup(self.backup, self.volume_file, False) def test_backup_disco_to_disco(self): """Test the method to backup a disco volume to a disco backend.""" with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_monitor_end_backup') as \ mock_monitor_backup: mock_monitor_backup.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.backup_disco_to_disco() self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertTrue(mock_monitor_backup.called) def test_backup_disco_to_disco_affect_backup_policy(self): """Test to backup a disco volume by affecting a backup policy.""" with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'affect_backup_policy_to_volume') as \ mock_affect: mock_affect.side_effect = \ self.affect_backup_policy_to_volume with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_monitor_end_backup') as \ mock_monitor_backup: mock_monitor_backup.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.backup_disco_to_disco() self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_affect.called) self.assertTrue(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertTrue(mock_monitor_backup.called) def test_backup_disco_to_disco_affect_backup_policy_fail(self): """Fail to backup a disco volume by affecting a backup policy.""" self.affect_bp_response = \ self.fake_affect_backup_policy_response['standard']['fail'] with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'affect_backup_policy_to_volume') as \ mock_affect: mock_affect.side_effect = \ self.affect_backup_policy_to_volume with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_monitor_end_backup') as \ mock_monitor_backup: mock_monitor_backup.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises( exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_affect.called) self.assertFalse(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertFalse(mock_monitor_backup.called) def test_backup_get_information_volume_fail(self): """Fail to get the volume's information during the backup.""" self.volume_info = self.volume_info_responses['fail'] with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_monitor_end_backup') as \ mock_monitor_backup: mock_monitor_backup.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertFalse(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertFalse(mock_monitor_backup.called) def test_do_backup_fail(self): """Fail to do the backup.""" self.do_backup_response = \ self.fake_do_backup_response['standard']['fail'] self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_monitor_end_backup') as \ mock_monitor_backup: mock_monitor_backup.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertFalse(mock_monitor_backup.called) def test_monitor_backup_request_fail(self): """Request to get the backup details return a failure.""" self.monitor_backup_status = \ self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['request_fail'] with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_backup_create: mock_backup_create.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_detail') as \ mock_backup_detail: mock_backup_detail.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_create.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_detail.called) def test_monitor_backup_fail(self): """Request to DISCO failed when monitoring the backup details.""" self.monitor_backup_status = \ self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['fail'] with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_do_backup: mock_do_backup.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_detail') as \ mock_backup_detail: mock_backup_detail.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_do_backup.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_detail.called) def test_monitor_backup_pending(self): """Get backup details rquest return pending then success.""" self.test_pending = True with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_backup_create: mock_backup_create.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_detail') as \ mock_backup_detail: mock_backup_detail.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.backup_disco_to_disco() self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_create.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_detail.called) @mock.patch.object(time, 'time') def test_monitor_backup_timeout(self, mock_time): """Backup detail request reaches timeout.""" timeout = 3 mock_time.side_effect = utils.generate_timeout_series(timeout) self.override_config("backup_check_timeout", timeout) self.monitor_backup_status = \ self.fake_backup_detail_response['backup_detail']['pending'] with mock.patch.object(self.driver, '_file_is_disco') as \ mock_file_is_disco: mock_file_is_disco.side_effect = self.fake_source_volume_type with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'volume_detail_by_id') as \ mock_volume_detail: mock_volume_detail.side_effect = self.get_volume_information self.volume_info['volumeInfoResult']['backupPolicyId'] = \ self.DEFAULT_BACKUP_POLICY with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_create') as \ mock_backup_create: mock_backup_create.side_effect = self.do_backup with mock.patch.object(self.driver.disco_src_api, 'backup_detail') as \ mock_backup_detail: mock_backup_detail.side_effect = \ self.monitor_end_backup self.assertRaises(exception.VolumeBackendAPIException, self.backup_disco_to_disco) self.assertTrue(mock_file_is_disco.called) self.assertTrue(mock_volume_detail.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_create.called) self.assertTrue(mock_backup_detail.called)

commit_message:
Adds lbaasv2 support for horizon

This adds neutron-lbaas-dashboard to openstack-dashboard for the v2 load balancer.

Change-Id: Id3d344a84813488f7a035e5cd3d73183b0a7ffe2
Closes-Bug:1592446

Add hacking check H106: Use the correct capitalization of OpenStack

Change-Id: Iec4b56ea2c6d83e545234b10949be2641d78ef6d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/47/153547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @core.flake8ext def hacking_openstack_correct_capitalization(physical_line): """Check that the correct capitalization of OpenStack is used. H106 use the correct capitalization of OpenStack Okay: OpenStack H106: Openstack H106: OpenStack Openstack """ if 'Openstack' in physical_line: pos = physical_line.find('Openstack') return (pos, "H106: Use the correct capitalization of OpenStack")

subject: Add resource status command for Workflow Engine
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-20 23:51:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/eb6b8e4fa84a1beabee06827106534afdbd0165c', 'message': 'WIP(do not merge) Add status command for Workflow Engine

Added a status command:
  kolla-kubernetes resource status svc keystone

The above will print out a yaml status dict of kube resources defined
by the resource_type.  The workflow engine may query the status of any
service from the perspective of kubernetes (e.g. is the resource
created, are the replication controllers in good states, etc).  The
output of this state is yaml, and the workflow engine may key off of
the top level "status: (ok|error)".

The file ./etc/kolla-kubernetes/services-resources.yml defines a list
of services and for each service a list of resource_types and a list
of files under each resource type.  In the keystone example below,
executing "kolla-kubernetes resource create svc keystone" will process
both of the files under the resource_type svc and send the output to
"kubectl create -f -" to create the resources.

  - name: keystone
    pods:
    - name: keystone
      containers:
      - name: keystone
    resources:
      disk:
      pv:
      pvc:
      svc:
      - services/keystone/keystone-service-admin.yml.j2
      - services/keystone/keystone-service-public.yml.j2
      bootstrap:
      - services/keystone/keystone-bootstrap-job.yml.j2
      pod:
      - services/keystone/keystone-pod.yml.j2

Any of the template files, once jinja processed, may generate a stream
of kube yaml resource definitions separated by "\n---\n".  This code
will first generate the template for a particular file, and then
individually feed each event to "kubectl describe -f -", while parsing
the output and executing checks based on the type of input.  For
example, for ReplicationControllers it checkes if desired_replicas ==
current_replicas.  Then, it sets the state (ok|error) of each segment,
which rolls up to the state of each template file, which rolls up to
the state of the resource_type for the service.  The resulting yaml is
printed to stdout as yaml, at which point operators may view the
result or workflow systems may key off of values such as the top-level
key "status: (ok|error)"

Sample Output:

$ kolla-kubernetes resource status svc keystone
"files":
- "errors": &id003 []
  "file": "/home/vagrant/Dev/kolla-kubernetes/services/keystone/keystone-service-admin.yml.j2"
  "ok": &id004 []
  "segments":
  - "errors": &id001 []
    "ok": &id002
    - "Verified resource with name keystone-admin exists"
    - "Service has IP"
    - "Verified resource with name keystone-public exists"
    - "Service has IP"
    "status": "ok"
  - "errors": *id001
    "ok": *id002
    "status": "ok"
  "status": "ok"
- "errors": *id003
  "file": "/home/vagrant/Dev/kolla-kubernetes/services/keystone/keystone-service-public.yml.j2"
  "ok": *id004
  "segments":
  - "errors": *id001
    "ok": *id002
    "status": "ok"
  - "errors": *id001
    "ok": *id002
    "status": "ok"
  "status": "ok"
"resource_type": "svc"
"service_name": "keystone"
"status": "ok"

Change-Id: Id3077b71800d348cc674d000104727a652ebfb83

commit_message:
Add resource status command for Workflow Engine

Added a status command:
  kolla-kubernetes resource status (pv|svc|pod|bootstrap|etc.) keystone

The above will print out the kubernetes status of all kube resources
defined by the resource_type template files, as a yaml dict to stdout.
The workflow engine may query the status of any service from the
perspective of kubernetes (e.g. is the pv/pvc/rc/svc in good
states, etc).  The output of this state is yaml, and the workflow
engine may key off of the top level "status: (ok|error)".

How this works: The services-resources.yml file defines a list of
services which has a tree of resource_types to lists of
resource-templates.  In the keystone example below, executing
"kolla-kubernetes resource create svc keystone" will serially process
each of the files under the resource_type svc and send the resulting
yaml streams to "kubectl create -f -" to create the resources.

./etc/kolla-kubernetes/services-resources.yml
  - name: keystone
    pods:
    - name: keystone
      containers:
      - name: keystone
    resources:
      disk:
      pv:
      pvc:
      svc:
      - services/keystone/keystone-service-admin.yml.j2
      - services/keystone/keystone-service-public.yml.j2
      bootstrap:
      - services/keystone/keystone-bootstrap-job.yml.j2
      pod:
      - services/keystone/keystone-pod.yml.j2

Any of the template files, once jinja processed, may generate a stream
of kube yaml resource definitions separated by "\n---\n".  This code
generates the template for a particular file, and then individually
feeds each event to "kubectl describe -f -", while parsing the output
and executing checks based on the type of input (e.g. RCs will check
if desired_replicas == current_replicas).  Then, it sets the state
(ok|error) of each segment, which rolls up to the state of the parent
template file, and finally to the parent resource_type for the
service.

sample_output$ kolla-kubernetes resource status pod keystone
meta:
  resource_type: pod
  service_name: keystone
results:
  status: ok
xdetails:
  templates:
  - meta:
      template: /home/vagrant/Dev/kolla-kubernetes/services/keystone/keystone-pod.yml.j2
    results:
      errors: []
      oks: []
      status: ok
    xdetails:
      segments:
      - meta:
          kind: ReplicationController
          name: keystone
        results:
          errors: []
          oks:
          - Verified resource with name keystone exists
          - ReplicationController replicas found
          - 'current == desired: 1 current / 1 desired'
          - ReplicationController pod_status found
          - 'pod_status has no errors: 1 Running / 0 Waiting / 0 Succeeded / 0 Failed'
          status: ok

Change-Id: Id3077b71800d348cc674d000104727a652ebfb83
Partially-implements: blueprint kolla-kubernetes-cli
Partially-implements: blueprint ansible-orchestration
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/02/345102/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import os import re from kolla_kubernetes.utils import ExecUtils from kolla_kubernetes.utils import YamlUtils class KubeResourceTemplate(object): """KubeResourceTemplate A KubeResourceTemplate is a jinja template, which when processed may generate a stream of kube resource definitions. In most cases, the output consists of a single kube resource yaml blob. Sometimes, the template may print nothing or whitespace (NO-OP). In other cases, the template may generate a stream of kube resource yaml blobs separated by "^---". We must handle all of these cases. """ errors = [] oks = [] kube_resources = [] def __init__(self, service_name, resource_type, kube_resource_template_path): # Check input args assert os.path.exists(kube_resource_template_path) # Initialize internal vars self.service_name = service_name self.resource_type = resource_type self.file_ = kube_resource_template_path self.doCheck() def getFile(self): return self.file_ def getStatus(self): if len(self.errors) != 0: return 'error' for kr in self.kube_resources: if kr.getStatus() != 'ok': return 'error' return 'ok' def asDict(self): res = {} res['status'] = self.getStatus() res['errors'] = self.errors res['ok'] = self.oks res['file'] = self.file_ res['segments'] = [] for kr in self.kube_resources: res['segments'].append(kr.asDict()) return res def doCheck(self): # Build the templating command cmd = "kolla-kubernetes resource-template {} {} {} {}".format( 'create', self.resource_type, self.service_name, self.file_) # Execute the command template_out, err = ExecUtils.exec_command(cmd) # Skip templates which which produce no-ops (100% whitespace) # (e.g. pv templates for AWS should not use persistent # volumes because AWS uses experimental # auto-provisioning) if (err is not None): self.errors.append( 'error processing template file: {}'.format(str(err))) return elif re.match("^\s+$", template_out): msg = "template {} produced empty output (NO-OP)".format( self.file_) self.oks.append(msg) return # Split the stream of kube resource yaml definitions definitions = re.split("^---", template_out, re.MULTILINE) for definition in definitions: kr = KubeResource(definition) self.kube_resources.append(kr) class KubeResource(object): errors = [] oks = [] def __init__(self, kube_resource_definition_yaml): # Check input args assert len(kube_resource_definition_yaml) > 0 # Initialize internal vars self.y = YamlUtils.yaml_dict_from_string(kube_resource_definition_yaml) self.doDescribeAndCheck() def getStatus(self): if len(self.errors) == 0: return 'ok' else: return 'error' def getKind(self): assert 'kind' in self.y return self.y['kind'] def getName(self): assert 'metadata' in self.y assert 'name' in self.y['metadata'] return self.y['metadata']['name'] def asDict(self): res = {} res['status'] = self.getStatus() res['errors'] = self.errors res['ok'] = self.oks return res def doDescribeAndCheck(self): cmd = ('echo "{}" | kubectl describe -f -'.format( YamlUtils.yaml_dict_to_string(self.y))) out, err = ExecUtils.exec_command(cmd) self.describe = out if err is not None: # If kubectl returns non-zero exit status we may end up here. self.errors.append('resource does not exist or input yaml invalid') return # For all resource types name = KubeResource._matchSingleLineField('Name', out) if name is None or name != self.getName(): self.errors.append( 'No resource with name {} exists'.format(self.getName())) else: self.oks.append( 'Verified resource with name {} exists'.format(self.getName())) # For PersistentVolumes and PersistentVolumeClaims if self.getKind() == 'PersistentVolume' or ( self.getKind() == 'PersistentVolumeClaim'): # Verify that it is bound status = KubeResource._matchSingleLineField('Status', out) if status is None or status != "Bound": self.errors.append("{} not Bound".format(self.getKind())) else: self.oks.append("{} Bound".format(self.getKind())) # For Services if self.getKind() == 'Service': # Verify the service has an IP ip = KubeResource._matchSingleLineField('IP', out) if ip is None or len(ip) == 0: self.errors.append("{} has no IP".format(self.getKind())) else: self.oks.append("{} has IP".format(self.getKind())) # For ReplicationControllers # Replicas: 1 current / 1 desired # Pods Status: 1 Running / 0 Waiting / 0 Succeeded / 0 Failed if self.getKind() == 'ReplicationController': # Verify the rc has the right number of replicas replicas = KubeResource._matchSingleLineField('Replicas', out) if replicas is None: self.errors.append( "{} replicas not found".format(self.getKind())) else: self.oks.append( "{} replicas found".format(self.getKind())) replicas_detail = KubeResource._matchReturnGroups( '^(\d+) current / (\d+) desired', replicas) if replicas_detail is not None: current, desired = replicas_detail if current != desired: self.errors.append( "current != desired: {}".format(replicas)) else: self.oks.append( "current == desired: {}".format(replicas)) # Verify the rc has the right number of pod_status pod_status = KubeResource._matchSingleLineField('Pods Status', out) if pod_status is None: self.errors.append( "{} pod_status not found".format(self.getKind())) else: self.oks.append( "{} pod_status found".format(self.getKind())) pod_status_detail = KubeResource._matchReturnGroups( '^(\d+) Running / (\d+) Waiting /' ' (\d+) Succeeded / (\d+) Failed', pod_status) if pod_status_detail is not None: running, waiting, succeeded, failed = pod_status_detail if (int(running) == 0 or int(waiting) > 0 or ( int(failed) > 0)): self.errors.append( "pod_status has errors {}".format(pod_status)) else: self.oks.append( "pod_status has no errors: {}".format(pod_status)) @staticmethod def _matchSingleLineField(field_name, haystack): """Returns field name's value""" match = re.search('^{}:\s+(?P<MY_VAL>.*)$'.format(field_name), haystack, re.MULTILINE) if match is None: return None else: return match.group('MY_VAL').strip() @staticmethod def _matchReturnGroups(regex, haystack): """Returns all groups matching regex""" match = re.search(regex, haystack, re.MULTILINE) if match is None: return None else: return match.groups()

www: Add id for title in draft-index.html

Add id tag per language. It is useful for translators
to jump to their language drafts directly.

commit_message:
Revert "Deploy and Upgrade Ironic to run in mod_wsgi"

It looks like node registration is failing randomly very often. Let's revert it now.

This reverts commit 7aefae4e41eb7ffb83675dffd1130dd8c6802287.

Change-Id: I53febcb01a2806fadaf688101925001da6188899
Partial-Bug: #1608252

commit_message:
Refactoring config options for cmd

Refactoring neutron configuration options for cmd to be in
neutron/conf. This would allow centralization of all configuration
options and provide an easy way to import.

Change-Id: I0bb7c88050aa5e931a53406d29b5b10c69c518bb
Partial-Bug: #1563069

commit_message:
Script to test horizon with wget or curl

This script checks whether wget or curl are installed and uses one of them to  perform
some http requests to the controller node trough the horizon (dashboard) interface, in
order to ensure that the service is working properly.

Change-Id: Ia2298a9dd117bed64f5e4c42858d6f1b125de07b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/87/349287/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #! /bin/bash ## This script access the OpenStack installation trough the dashboard by making ## wget or curl requests (whichever is available). ## It goes in this order: ## 1: retrieve cookie ## 2: use that cookie for authenticating with user/password and get the session id ## 3: use the session id and token for getting the (provider) network id ## 4: similar to step 3 but get the ID of the cirros image ## 5: launch an instance using the data from steps 2,3 and 4 HOST="http://10.0.0.11" AUTH_URL="$HOST/horizon/auth/login/" DOMAIN="default" USER="admin" PASSWORD="admin_user_secret" COOKIE_FILE="cookie.txt" OUTPUT_FILE1="output.1.html" OUTPUT_FILE2="output.2.html" OUTPUT_FILE3="output.3.html" OUTPUT_FILE4="output.4.html" OUTPUT_FILE5="output.5.html" # Clean before starting rm $COOKIE_FILE $OUTPUT_FILE1 $OUTPUT_FILE2 $OUTPUT_FILE3 $OUTPUT_FILE4 \ $OUTPUT_FILE5 &> /dev/null unset REQUEST_TOOL COOKIE_ARG POST_ARG DATA TOKEN SESSIONID # Ensure wget or curl are installed if which gwget &> /dev/null ; then #echo "wget is installed, using wget" REQUEST_TOOL="wget" elif which curl &> /dev/null; then #echo "curl is installed, using curl" REQUEST_TOOL="curl" else echo "ERROR: neither wget nor curl were found. Please install one with:" echo " apt-get -y install wget" exit 1 fi request_cmd () { # Usage: # request_cmd URL OUT_FILE POST_DATA REFERER URL=$1 OUTPUT_FILE=$2 DATA=$3 REFERER=$4 [ ! -z $REFERER ] && REFERER_ARG="--referer $REFERER" if [ "$REQUEST_TOOL" = "wget" ]; then [ -f $COOKIE_FILE ] && COOKIE_ARG="--load-cookies=$COOKIE_FILE" [ ! -z $DATA ] && POST_ARG="--post-data=$DATA" #echo "wget --quiet --keep-session-cookies --save-cookies $COOKIE_FILE \ # "$COOKIE_ARG" "$POST_ARG" "$REFERER_ARG" \ # --output-document=$OUTPUT_FILE $URL" #echo wget --quiet --keep-session-cookies --save-cookies "$COOKIE_FILE" \ "$COOKIE_ARG" "$POST_ARG" "$REFERER_ARG" \ --output-document="$OUTPUT_FILE" "$URL" elif [ "$REQUEST_TOOL" = "curl" ]; then [ ! -z $DATA ] && POST_ARG="-d $DATA" curl -L -c $COOKIE_FILE -b $COOKIE_FILE $POST_ARG --output $OUTPUT_FILE \ $REFERER_ARG -s $URL fi } # Step 1: get the cookie request_cmd $AUTH_URL $OUTPUT_FILE1 TOKEN=`cat $COOKIE_FILE | grep csrftoken | sed 's/^.*csrftoken\s*//'` DATA="username=$USER&password=$PASSWORD&domain=$DOMAIN&csrfmiddlewaretoken=$TOKEN" # Step 2: check the login credentials and obtains the session ID request_cmd $AUTH_URL $OUTPUT_FILE2 $DATA # Check that "sessionid" appears in the cookie file SESSIONID=`cat $COOKIE_FILE | grep sessionid | sed 's/^.*sessionid\s*//'` if [ "$SESSIONID" == "" ]; then echo "Error: sessionid not present on file $COOKIE_FILE ...Exit" exit 1 else echo "Login successful" fi TOKEN=`cat $COOKIE_FILE | grep csrftoken | sed 's/^.*csrftoken\s*//'` NET_URL="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/project/networks/" REFERER="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/identity/" DATA="login_region='http://controller:5000/v3'&login_domain=default&csrfmiddlewaretoken=\ $TOKEN&sessionid=$SESSIONID" # Step 3: Load the page with the networks request_cmd $NET_URL $OUTPUT_FILE3 $DATA $REFERER # Parse (provider) network ID NET_ID=$(grep "provider" $OUTPUT_FILE3 | \ awk -F"data-object-id=" '{print $2}' | \ awk -F'"' '{print $2}') echo "NET_ID="$NET_ID TOKEN=`cat $COOKIE_FILE | grep csrftoken | sed 's/^.*csrftoken\s*//'` NET_URL="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/project/images/" REFERER="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/identity/" DATA="login_region='http://controller:5000/v3'&login_domain=default&csrfmiddlewaretoken=\ $TOKEN&sessionid=$SESSIONID" # Step 4: Load the page with the available images request_cmd $NET_URL $OUTPUT_FILE4 $DATA $REFERER # Parse (cirros) image ID IMAGE_ID=$(grep "cirros" $OUTPUT_FILE4 | \ awk -F"obj_id=" '{print $2}' | \ awk -F'"' '{print $1}') echo "IMAGE_ID="$IMAGE_ID ## Launching an instance #TOKEN=`cat $COOKIE_FILE | grep csrftoken | sed 's/^.*csrftoken\s*//'` # #LAUNCH_URL="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/project/instances/" #REFERER="http://10.0.0.11/horizon/project/instances/" # ##Header captured from Firefox ##{"availability_zone":"nova","config_drive":false,"user_data":"","disk_config":"AUTO","instance_count":1,"name":"osbash_test_instance","profile":{},"security_groups":[],"source_id":"5b8eb98b-c325-42db-a38c-f0a994622877","flavor_id":"1","nics":[{"net-id":"0a7441ff-672a-47cd-81b7-520a286c6d15","v4-fixed-ip":""}],"key_name":null} # #DATA="login_region='http://controller:5000/v3'&login_domain=default&csrfmiddlewaretoken=\ #$TOKEN&sessionid=$SESSIONID&availability_zone=nova&disk_config=AUTO&\ #name=osbash_test_instance1&source_id=$IMAGE_ID&flavor_id=1&key_name=null&\ #nics=[{net-id=$NET_ID}]" # #request_cmd $LAUNCH_URL $OUTPUT_FILE5 $DATA $REFERER ## The last command doesn't work because there is something wrong either in DATA or ## in LAUNCH_URL (maybe GET parameters?)

commit_message:
Use ntp wait time as 10 min instead of 100

By default ntp-wait waits 6 sec * 1000 tries = 100 mins
It breaks long jobs like in TripleO projects because of waiting
for 1 hour 40 minutes. If ntp wasn't synced during first 10 min
it most likely won't be synced at all, so no reason to wait so
long time and break jobs that date is not critical for them

Change-Id: Iae28a03829a255f0990934685d8c2e563a7a8492
Partial-Bug: 1608226

commit_message:
Configure Nova [cache] options correctly (Mitaka only)

During Mitaka, Nova deprecated memcached_servers option [1] and cache
options should now be in [cache] section in nova.conf.

We added [cache] options in puppet-nova:
I5b10ac89db41d5ed8d283c1673a6fdec5bfbc66c

This patch aims to use it on controllers.
The problem has been fixed in master with composable roles, directly in
the Nova profile in puppet-tripleo, so we couldn't backport it into
stable/mitaka.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/nova/mitaka.html

Change-Id: Ia92ca5d40abd81d20cb7bf1b295f565b4432dcb1
Depends-On: I5b10ac89db41d5ed8d283c1673a6fdec5bfbc66c

commit_message:
Create an executable file for daemon_factory

This patch introduces an executable file for damon_factory
process under /usr/local/bin, which is splitted out from
previous python code under /usr/local/lib.

This patch also introduces storlets_agent package for agent
programs inside docker container, which will include codes
for python storlet application support in the future.

Change-Id: I262f13a32e018913e00350b5f6ebc7b5a5c5ae44

commit_message:
Add hacking rule for explicit import of _ function

Change-Id: Id0c1610f0b6353a43341f704e0b4b00bd04828bb
Closes-bug: #1490194
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/17/347517/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: UNDERSCORE_IMPORT_FILES = [] session_check = re.compile(r"\w*def [a-zA-Z0-9].*[(].*session.*[)]") cfg_re = re.compile(r".*\scfg\.") cfg_opt_re = re.compile(r".*[\s\[]cfg\.[a-zA-Z]*Opt\(") policy_enforce_re = re.compile(r".*_ENFORCER\.enforce\(") vi_header_re = re.compile(r"^#\s+vim?:.+") asse_raises_regexp = re.compile(r"assertRaisesRegexp\(") conf_attribute_set_re = re.compile(r"CONF\.[a-z0-9_.]+\s*=\s*\w") log_translation = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(audit|error|critical)\(\s*('|\")") log_translation_info = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(info)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") log_translation_exception = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(exception)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") log_translation_LW = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(warning|warn)\(\s*(_\(|'|\")") translated_log = re.compile( r"(.)*LOG\.(audit|error|info|critical|exception)" "\(\s*_\(\s*('|\")") string_translation = re.compile(r"[^_]*_\(\s*('|\")") underscore_import_check = re.compile(r"(.)*import _(.)*") import_translation_for_log_or_exception = re.compile( r"(.)*(from\smagnum.i18n\simport)\s_") # We need this for cases where they have created their own _ function. custom_underscore_check = re.compile(r"(.)*_\s*=\s*(.)*") api_version_re = re.compile(r"@.*api_version") decorator_re = re.compile(r"@.*") contextlib_nested = re.compile(r"^with (contextlib\.)?nested\(") doubled_words_re = re.compile( r"\b(then?|[iao]n|i[fst]|but|f?or|at|and|[dt]o)\s+\1\b") opt_help_text_min_char_count = 10def no_db_session_in_public_api(logical_line, filename): if "db/api.py" in filename: if session_check.match(logical_line): yield (0, "M309: public db api methods may not accept session") def capital_cfg_help(logical_line, tokens): msg = "M313: capitalize help string" if cfg_re.match(logical_line): for t in range(len(tokens)): if tokens[t][1] == "help": txt = tokens[t + 2][1] if len(txt) > 1 and txt[1].islower(): yield(0, msg) def check_policy_enforce(logical_line, filename): """Look for uses of magnum.policy._ENFORCER.enforce() Now that policy defaults are registered in code the _ENFORCER.authorize method should be used. That ensures that only registered policies are used. Uses of _ENFORCER.enforce could allow unregistered policies to be used, so this check looks for uses of that method. M351 """ msg = ('M351: magnum.policy._ENFORCER.enforce() should not be used. ' 'Use the authorize() method instead.') if policy_enforce_re.match(logical_line): yield(0, msg) def no_vi_headers(physical_line, line_number, lines): """Check for vi editor configuration in source files. By default vi modelines can only appear in the first or last 5 lines of a source file. M314 """ # NOTE(gilliard): line_number is 1-indexed if line_number <= 5 or line_number > len(lines) - 5: if vi_header_re.match(physical_line): return 0, "M314: Don't put vi configuration in source files" def assert_raises_regexp(logical_line): """Check for usage of deprecated assertRaisesRegexp M335 """ res = asse_raises_regexp.search(logical_line) if res: yield (0, "M335: assertRaisesRegex must be used instead " "of assertRaisesRegexp") def no_setting_conf_directly_in_tests(logical_line, filename): """Check for setting CONF.* attributes directly in tests The value can leak out of tests affecting how subsequent tests run. Using self.flags(option=value) is the preferred method to temporarily set config options in tests. M320 """ if 'magnum/tests/' in filename: res = conf_attribute_set_re.match(logical_line) if res: yield (0, "M320: Setting CONF.* attributes directly in tests is " "forbidden. Use self.flags(option=value) instead") def validate_log_translations(logical_line, physical_line, filename): # Translations are not required in the test directory # and the Xen utilities if ("magnum/tests" in filename): return if pep8.noqa(physical_line): return msg = "M328: LOG.info messages require translations `_LI()`!" if log_translation_info.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M329: LOG.exception messages require translations `_LE()`!" if log_translation_exception.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M330: LOG.warning, LOG.warn messages require translations `_LW()`!" if log_translation_LW.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) msg = "M321: Log messages require translations!" if log_translation.match(logical_line): yield (0, msg) def check_explicit_underscore_import(logical_line, filename): """Check for explicit import of the _ function We need to ensure that any files that are using the _() function to translate logs are explicitly importing the _ function. We can't trust unit test to catch whether the import has been added so we need to check for it here. """ # Build a list of the files that have _ imported. No further # checking needed once it is found. if filename in UNDERSCORE_IMPORT_FILES: pass elif (underscore_import_check.match(logical_line) or custom_underscore_check.match(logical_line)): UNDERSCORE_IMPORT_FILES.append(filename) elif (translated_log.match(logical_line) or string_translation.match(logical_line)): yield(0, "M323: Found use of _() without explicit import of _ !") def no_import_translation_in_tests(logical_line, filename): """Check for 'from magnum.i18n import _' M337 """ if 'magnum/tests/' in filename: res = import_translation_for_log_or_exception.match(logical_line) if res: yield(0, "M337 Don't import translation in tests") def check_api_version_decorator(logical_line, previous_logical, blank_before, filename): msg = ("M332: the api_version decorator must be the first decorator" " on a method.") if blank_before == 0 and re.match(api_version_re, logical_line) \ and re.match(decorator_re, previous_logical): yield(0, msg) def check_no_contextlib_nested(logical_line, filename): msg = ("M341: contextlib.nested is deprecated. With Python 2.7 and later " "the with-statement supports multiple nested objects. See https://" "docs.python.org/2/library/contextlib.html#contextlib.nested for " "more information. magnum.test.nested() is an alternative as well.") if contextlib_nested.match(logical_line): yield(0, msg) def check_doubled_words(physical_line, filename): """Check for the common doubled-word typos M343 """ msg = ("M343: Doubled word '%(word)s' typo found") match = re.search(doubled_words_re, physical_line) if match: return (0, msg % {'word': match.group(1)}) def cfg_help_with_enough_text(logical_line, tokens): # TODO(markus_z): The count of 10 chars is the *highest* number I could # use to introduce this new check without breaking the gate. IOW, if I # use a value of 15 for example, the gate checks will fail because we have # a few config options which use fewer chars than 15 to explain their # usage (for example the options "ca_file" and "cert"). # As soon as the implementation of bp centralize-config-options is # finished, I wanted to increase that magic number to a higher (to be # defined) value. # This check is an attempt to programmatically check a part of the review # guidelines http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/code-review.html msg = ("M347: A config option is a public interface to the cloud admins " "and should be properly documented. A part of that is to provide " "enough help text to describe this option. Use at least %s chars " "for that description. Is is likely that this minimum will be " "increased in the future." % opt_help_text_min_char_count) if not cfg_opt_re.match(logical_line): return # ignore DeprecatedOpt objects. They get mentioned in the release notes # and don't need a lengthy help text anymore if "DeprecatedOpt" in logical_line: return def get_token_value(idx): return tokens[idx][1] def get_token_values(start_index, length): values = "" for offset in range(length): values += get_token_value(start_index + offset) return values def get_help_token_index(): for idx in range(len(tokens)): if get_token_value(idx) == "help": return idx return -1 def has_help(): return get_help_token_index() >= 0 def get_trimmed_help_text(t): txt = "" # len(["help", "=", "_", "("]) ==> 4 if get_token_values(t, 4) == "help=_(": txt = get_token_value(t + 4) # len(["help", "=", "("]) ==> 3 elif get_token_values(t, 3) == "help=(": txt = get_token_value(t + 3) # len(["help", "="]) ==> 2 else: txt = get_token_value(t + 2) return " ".join(txt.strip('\"\'').split()) def has_enough_help_text(txt): return len(txt) >= opt_help_text_min_char_count if has_help(): t = get_help_token_index() txt = get_trimmed_help_text(t) if not has_enough_help_text(txt): yield(0, msg) else: yield(0, msg) register(no_db_session_in_public_api) register(capital_cfg_help) register(cfg_help_with_enough_text) register(check_policy_enforce) register(no_vi_headers) register(assert_raises_regexp) register(no_setting_conf_directly_in_tests) register(validate_log_translations) register(check_explicit_underscore_import) register(no_import_translation_in_tests) register(check_api_version_decorator) register(check_no_contextlib_nested) register(check_doubled_words)

commit_message:
No more no-unneeded-ternary eslint errors

Running eslint is effectively useless nowdays because of the
overwhelming number of warnings returned.

This patch fixes the existing "no-unneeded-ternary" errors.

I've decided to only fix those errors here to keep the patch small, and
not destroy any chance of success by needing to rebase every 5 minutes.
Other fixes will be incoming.

Change-Id: I0d6d104560dc3b6cc10cc3ff00e45230ce5fa836
Partial-Bug: #1554824

commit_message:
Add Python 3.5 classifier and venv

Now that there is a passing gate job, we can claim support for
Python 3.5 in the classifier. This patch also adds the convenience
py35 venv.

Change-Id: Ieca09d7eb44f056aabe36dcf6eab4bf5dbf815eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/77/341077/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py35,py34,py27,pep8[testenv:py35] basepython = python3.5 [testenv:debug35] basepython = python3.5 commands = oslo_debug_helper -t tests {posargs}

commit_message:
Deploy and Upgrade Ironic to run in mod_wsgi

* Deploy and upgrade Ironic API to mod_wsgi with Apache.
* Make sure RabbitMQ is started before Apache.
  If it's not the case, Ironic API won't start correctly, see
  https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1564075 for details.

Change-Id: I83953eb88a86a631d22a917c9fc997f59909e814

revisions:

Test "test_create_get_delete_share" located in
"manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_shares.py" assumes

commit_message:
Fix race condition in tempest test

Test "test_create_get_delete_share" located in
"manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_shares.py" assumes
that share is created not so fast and has "creating" status.
But it can be "available" in case of really fast creation
as in case of "dummy" driver.

Change-Id: Ie8a01e9352da47ff6e47ad8baeb5409282d3305c
Closes-Bug: #1607723
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/29/348829/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # set and have value either 'creating' or # 'available' (if share creation is really fast as in # case of Dummy driver). self.assertIn(share['status'], ('creating', 'available')) # set and have value either 'creating' or # 'available' (if share creation is really fast as in # case of Dummy driver). self.assertIn(child['status'], ('creating', 'available'))
deleted_lines: # the default value - 'creating'. self.assertEqual('creating', share['status']) # the default value - 'creating'. self.assertEqual('creating', child['status'])

commit_message:
Add initial err2d2 project config

This new project will start to unify the various bots
in openstack and get them (all?) based off of errbot
plugins that can then be assembled into a useful bot
in various manners.

Needed-By: I89531642053bd86c7b4102e5e8ed126c7878908c
Change-Id: Ie078255c672e6e6dbb2c9f8373bdf79039c115e5

commit_message:
Change main function

In main function sys.exit will exit python interpreter .
 Now we can call the main() as below to avoid to exit
the interactive interpreter and specify the return value of main()
in exit code.

Change-Id: I95915f1f8b345bd3b3a6a3ae9e3ee34e814380fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/17/349217/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return return return 1 sys.exit(main())

subject: Import mock so that it works on Python 3.x
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-29 21:29:53.000000000', 'files': ['oslotest/tests/unit/test_timeout.py', 'oslotest/tests/unit/test_output.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslotest/commit/425d4651221d09141afd1de1367cf1ec188594ca', 'message': 'Import mock so that it works on Python 3.x

Running oslotest's tests fail on Python 3.x because of the "import mock"
lines in test_output.py and test_timeout.py.  That works for 2.x because
"mock" is an independent package, but in 3.x, it's a part of unittest in
the standard library.  This difference is covered in six.moves, which is
where mock is imported from in other test modules.

Change-Id: I3882c2a9be8abc93cf95942579cb9562c6377c01
Closes-Bug: #1607963
'}]
commit_message:
Import mock so that it works on Python 3.x

Running oslotest's tests fail on Python 3.x because of the "import mock"
lines in test_output.py and test_timeout.py.  That works for 2.x because
"mock" is an independent package, but in 3.x, it's a part of unittest in
the standard library.  This difference is covered in six.moves, which is
where mock is imported from in other test modules.

Change-Id: I3882c2a9be8abc93cf95942579cb9562c6377c01
Closes-Bug: #1607963
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslotest refs/changes/75/349075/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from six.moves import mock

commit_message:
Host evacuation using nova

Evacuate instance from compute node using
nova host-evacuate-live except host_evacuation.sh script

Change-Id: I01a04cfa1ed2aafce7987e523e6b589dea21fbb0
(cherry picked from commit 013a7ded2275245a38ee58289dac2bc8b90fa37e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/50/349250/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import timefrom octane.util import nova call_host = self.node.data['fqdn'] nova.run_nova_cmd( ["nova", "service-enable", call_host, "nova-compute"], controller, False) call_host = self.node.data['fqdn'].split('.', 1)[0] nova.run_nova_cmd( ["nova", "service-enable", call_host, "nova-compute"], controller, False) @staticmethod def _get_list_instances(controller): compute_list_str = nova.run_nova_cmd([ "nova", "service-list", "|", "awk", "'/nova-compute/ {print $6\"|\"$10}'"], controller, True) enabled_compute = [] disabled_computes = set() for line in compute_list_str.splitlines(): fqdn, status = line.split('|') if status == "enabled": enabled_compute.append(fqdn) elif status == "disabled": enabled_compute.add(fqdn) return (enabled_compute, disabled_computes) @staticmethod def _waiting_for_migration_ends(controller, node_fqdn, attempts=180, attempt_delay=10): for _ in attempts: LOG.info("Waiting until migration ends") result = nova.run_nova_cmd(['nova', 'list', '--host', node_fqdn, '--status', 'MIGRATING', '--limit', '1'], controller) # nova list has no option to remove menu form so empty has 4 rows if len(result.strip().splitlines()) != 4: time.sleep(attempt_delay) enabled_compute, disabled_computes = self._get_list_instances( controller) if len(enabled_compute) < 2: raise Exception("You can't disable last enabled compute") node_fqdn = node_util.get_nova_node_handle(self.node) if node_fqdn in disabled_computes: LOG.warn("Node {0} already disabled".format(node_fqdn)) else: nova.run_nova_cmd( ["nova", "service-disable", node_fqdn, "nova-compute"], controller, False) nova.run_nova_cmd(['nova', 'host-evacuate-live', node_fqdn], controller, False) self._waiting_for_migration_ends(controller, node_fqdn)
deleted_lines: import stat ssh.call( ["sh", "-c", ". /root/openrc; " "nova service-enable {0} nova-compute".format( self.node.data['fqdn'])], node=controller, ) ssh.call( ["sh", "-c", ". /root/openrc; " "nova service-enable {0} nova-compute".format( self.node.data['fqdn'].split('.', 1)[0])], node=controller, ) with ssh.tempdir(controller) as tempdir: local_path = os.path.join( magic_consts.CWD, 'bin', 'host_evacuation.sh') remote_path = os.path.join(tempdir, 'host_evacuation.sh') sftp = ssh.sftp(controller) sftp.put(local_path, remote_path) sftp.chmod(remote_path, stat.S_IRWXO) ssh.call( [remote_path, node_util.get_nova_node_handle(self.node)], node=controller, )
